class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Polish Pączki Cafe’s recipe calls for a few ingredients — sugar, yeast, milk, eggs, butter and flour, and a pinch of salt — But the details matter. Butter is imported from Poland, flour is sifted, yeast is fresh, only egg yolks are used and a splash of alcohol (preferably Polish spirytus) is added to “cut the grease.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>There she met her now-friend and business partner Bożena Zakrzewski. When a longtime Polish restaurant closed in 2018, the two decided they “had to do something” and opened Polish Pączki Cafe.</p><p>The 77-year-old still remembers watching her mother mix dough in a giant bowl in a village in Poland’s Podlasie region as a child. Decades later, Niziołek recalled, when her mother, Janina, visited her at the Old Warsaw, she would inspect her pączki and give suggestions on how to refine the formula.</p><p>The recipe is surprisingly simple. It calls for sugar, yeast, milk, eggs, butter and flour, and a pinch of salt. But the details matter. Butter is imported from Poland, flour is sifted, yeast is fresh, only egg yolks are used and a splash of alcohol (preferably Polish spirytus) is added to “cut the grease.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/476e04a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6428x3608+0+339/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdd%2Ff1%2F604b06d64b95be5102e590627f28%2Fpaczkiday-260217-15.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Paczki is fried at Polish Paczki Cafe in Norwood Park, Saturday, Jan. 31, 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/476e04a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6428x3608+0+339/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdd%2Ff1%2F604b06d64b95be5102e590627f28%2Fpaczkiday-260217-15.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/42527d3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6428x3608+0+339/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdd%2Ff1%2F604b06d64b95be5102e590627f28%2Fpaczkiday-260217-15.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/476e04a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6428x3608+0+339/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdd%2Ff1%2F604b06d64b95be5102e590627f28%2Fpaczkiday-260217-15.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>How many pączki are fried, and when, depends on the length of the line in the store. At Polish Pączki Cafe never sit on display. Still warm, they are glazed with a mixture of lemon juice and powdered sugar, topped with orange zest, packed in boxes and taken straight to the customer.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Fresh and imported ingredients, along with the laborious process, are reflected in the pączki price: one is $3.25 with tax. The owners said they haven’t raised it this year, but they may be forced to do so at any moment due to the rising cost of ingredients. They also vow not to change their recipe, their handmade process or to introduce other fillings.</p><p>“They won’t be our pączki anymore,” Zakrzewski said. “They will be just like everyone else’s.”</p><p>Preparation for Fat Thursday starts the morning the day before, when the restaurant pauses regular service and makes a few thousand handmade pączki over 36 hours straight. Overnight, up to two dozen women make pączki at a few stations, while several others focus on frying, glazing and packing. The cafe will be open from 10 a.m. Wednesday through 7 p.m. Thursday, including overnight.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-680000" name="image-680000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f10ea9c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+369/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F7d%2F87aece434847accf51ac0417dd9b%2Fpaczkiday-260217-12.jpg width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7248c0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+369/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F7d%2F87aece434847accf51ac0417dd9b%2Fpaczkiday-260217-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="PACZKIDAY_260217_12.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7248c0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+369/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F7d%2F87aece434847accf51ac0417dd9b%2Fpaczkiday-260217-12.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/745b473/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+369/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F7d%2F87aece434847accf51ac0417dd9b%2Fpaczkiday-260217-12.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7248c0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+369/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F7d%2F87aece434847accf51ac0417dd9b%2Fpaczkiday-260217-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Owners Anna Niziolek (left) and Bozena Zakrzewski (second from left) shape paczki dough with their employees at Polish Pączki Cafe. The filling — a mix of plum, rose and raspberry marmalades imported from Poland — is hand-folded into the dough before frying, rather than injected afterward.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“We need all hands on deck,” said Zakrzewski, who is in the kitchen the whole time overseeing the production.</p><p>Half of the pączki fulfills preorders from companies, factories and large groups, including from Wisconsin and Indiana. The other half go to the customers in line.</p><p>Kąsek, a regular at the cafe, vows he will wait in line no matter how long it is.</p><p>But how many can one eat?</p><p>“As many as the doctor allows,” he said with a laugh. For those trying to cut on calories, there’s always a baked option, also offered at the Polish Pączki Cafe, along with other pastries. But original pączki are a must here.</p>
entries.author: Joanna Marszałek

entries.title: Chicago’s Nick Cave is digging up America’s bones at a fraught moment for the Smithsonian
entries.summary: <p>On a cerulean blue Tuesday in early January, artist Nick Cave directs an uncanny scene unfolding along the Chicago lakefront. Three enormous mammoths lumber south toward the city’s silhouetted skyline.</p><p>It’s around 11 a.m., but the scene feels out of time, hovering between past and present.</p><div class="Enhancement target="_blank" >Privacy Policy</a></p> </div> </form> </bsp-form> </div> </div><p>Built from open metal frames wrapped in long, wispy hair, each creature is animated by four people walking in unison. But their bodies are not the kind of Woolly mammoth reconstructions typically found in museum dioramas. Moving across the horizon, the mammoths appear partially decomposed, as if recently unearthed from an ancient, Arctic permafrost.</p><p>“Stop!” Cave calls out, his voice carried by the blustering winter wind. “Let’s do that again.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-fullBleed> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-0a0000" alt="Dancers donning the mammoth costume walk past with the city skyline in the background for the video portion of “Nick Cave: Mammoth” a series by artist Nick Cave during a video shoot near the Theater by the Lake at North DuSable Lakeshore Drive and West Fullerton Parkway on the lakefront, Tuesday, Jan. 13, 2026. Nick Cave will be presenting work at the Smithsonian American Art Museum that will be immersive experience with crafted hides and bones of mammoths, a video projection of the mammoths come to life, found objects. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a76dd0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0e%2Fe7%2F44478a4f4e159105300cc7d659b7%2Fnickcave-260215-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d9201bc/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0e%2Fe7%2F44478a4f4e159105300cc7d659b7%2Fnickcave-260215-04.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a76dd0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0e%2Fe7%2F44478a4f4e159105300cc7d659b7%2Fnickcave-260215-04.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Cave designed the ancient creatures in “Mammoth” with the Chicago metal fabrication studio Manifold. The works are animated by four people walking in unison. In January, the artist took them for a stroll on the Chicago lakefront.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><b>Art in a moment of ‘incredible upheaval’</b></h3><p>The mammalian puppets are in fact the stars of Cave’s new film installation, “Roam,” one of several works the artist has created for his eponymous exhibition “Mammoth” at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C.</p><p>The exhibition, which opens on Friday and remains on view through January of next year, is the museum’s largest ever single-artist commission. The decision to showcase a queer Black artist is not lost on Cave, who lives and works in Chicago. And the eerie sense of resurrection, he says, is intentional.</p><p>“I was reflecting on what’s going on at the Smithsonian in terms of erasing history and shifting the narrative,” he reflects. “This whole notion of disappearing, dissolving.” And yet, he adds, history has a way of resurfacing. “That’s our mammoth. We’re still digging up bones.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-bc0000" 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ef704f5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbf%2F95%2F516516d74d0490bf411accb7d8dc%2Fnickcave-260215-11.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“I was reflecting on what’s going on at the Smithsonian in terms of erasing history and shifting the narrative,” Cave reflects. “This whole notion of disappearing, dissolving.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Last March, the Trump administration issued the executive order titled “Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History,” which criticizes the Smithsonian for promoting what it calls “divisive race-centered ideology.” The order puts the museum campus under federal scrutiny by authorizing reviews of exhibitions and programming. The goal, it reads, is to emphasize "American exceptionalism" and remove what the Trump administration calls "partisan narratives."</p><p>Officials have warned federal funding could be withheld if the museums don't comply. But the directive has prompted resignations and high-profile artist cancellations, such as by painter Amy Sherald.</p><p>In a moment of “incredible upheaval,” says Sarah Newman, the James Dicke Curator of Contemporary Art and acting head curator at SAAM, “Nick is proposing a way to navigate through that change, a way to look at our environment and our heritage, take solace in it, honor and learn from it, and look toward creativity as a way to locate your place in the world.”</p><p>At 67, Cave is best known for <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/culture-the-arts/2022/05/19/artist-nick-cave-and-his-soundsuits-take-over-chicago-mca-dusable" target="_blank" ><u>his Soundsuits,</u></a> folkloric, futuristic sculptural forms that blur the line between costume and armor. Sometimes glittering, other times spectral, the suits evoke both Maurice Sendak’s “wild things” and the heightened drama of Schiaparelli couture.</p><p>Cave began making the Soundsuits in 1991 in response to the brutal Los Angeles Police Department beating of Rodney King, a Black man whose assault ignited the 1992 L.A. riots, and national outrage, over police brutality. Since then, Cave estimates he has made nearly 500 suits, each an expression of his expansive, inimitable imagination.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/262e018/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc6%2F65%2Fd4e047f24b38b276a0b8c579067e%2F7i6a8158.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bdd5d0d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc6%2F65%2Fd4e047f24b38b276a0b8c579067e%2F7i6a8158.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Cave is best known for his Soundsuits, folkloric, futuristic sculptural forms that blur the line between costume and armor. Here the Soundsuits are pictured in an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago in 2022.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>A former dancer who trained at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Cave has long straddled the worlds of fashion, performance and art. He is a professor of fashion studies at the School of the Art Institute and has exhibited widely across the United States, including major solo exhibitions at the Guggenheim, MASS MoCA, and the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago.</p><p>In Chicago, one of Cave’s Soundsuits is currently on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago as part of the show, “City in a Garden: Queer Art and Activism in Chicago.” Two additional pieces hang in the Art Institute of Chicago exhibition “On Loss and Absence.” On the South Side, Cave designed the floral-inspired mosaic ceiling at the Washington Park Green Line stop and will unveil a new commission for the Obama Presidential Center later this spring.</p><p>Cave and his partner in life and art, Bob Faust, also run a gallery from their expansive live-work space, Facility, in Old Irving Park.</p><p>While Cave’s work seems to dance, often literally. around overt political declarations, the artist doesn't shy from pointed critique. “Is the work somewhat political?” Cave asks, rhetorically. “Oh yeah, it’s in there.”</p><p>All of Cave’s creations hold grief and celebration, agony and ecstasy, in equal measure.</p><h3><b>A legacy of craftmaking and meticulous handiwork</b></h3><p>For Cave, the Smithsonian show began with a personal excavation. “I started thinking, how was I made?” says Cave. “How did I become who I am?”</p><p>Cave grew up one of seven brothers in Missouri. Many of his favorite memories were shaped on his grandparents’ farm where he was surrounded by aunts and uncles who made things with their hands. “They were all just making stuff anyway, but didn’t call it art,” recalls Cave. “It was really just hobbies, craftsmanship. Things they did on Saturdays and Sundays.”</p><p>As a boy, Cave especially loved watching his grandmother work. “At seven o’clock, she would say, ‘Knick Knack, go pull my quilt out of the chest,’” he recalls, “and she would sit down and just start to quilt.” He also remembers how his grandmother would cut clothing patterns from brown paper bags, pin them directly onto one of her many grandchildren, and assemble garments in a matter of hours.</p><p>But the making was only part of it. Pageantry mattered, too. When a quilt or painting was finished, “there would be this big reveal,” says Cave. “Something about it was magical.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-fullBleed> <div class="Enhancement-item" 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/28338d4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0c%2Ffb%2Fd4e3aa8e4c0b927d823b715b9fac%2Fnickcave-260215-37.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The artist is one of seven boys in a family of makers who spent their weekends stitching, beading and making things with their hands. He incorporates beadwork into his new exhibition.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Cave’s memories weave through exhibition, which includes “Roam;” a series of five towering lifeguard chairs; figurative bronze sculptures molded from Cave’s own body; and a 60-foot beaded curtain that hangs over a mural designed by Cave’s partner, Faust, inspired by the Missouri farm. Cave’s mammoths also appear throughout the gallery spaces, some in full form, others reduced to skulls or tusks.</p><p>The show’s most intimate work, however, sprawls across a 70-foot light table. Titled “A Lit History,” the massive assemblage is created from thousands of objects — pie pans, nails, trivets, bingo ball cages, thimbles, crocheted doilies, metal coils — that Cave has collected over the last three decades, many of them from his grandparents’ house. Those unadorned, everyday items sit alongside elaborate pieces of Cave’s own invention: veils fashioned from plastic ties and price tags, hats assembled from knobbed keychain rings, and garments stitched from tens of thousands of buttons.</p><p>It registers in two ways at once. From a distance, “A Lit History” provokes sheer bewilderment and wonder; up close, the display reveals intricate and meticulous craftsmanship.</p><p>“Nick has this unique ability to see beauty and art in things that people would otherwise be so quick to discard or not value,” says Michelle Boone, the president of the Poetry Foundation and former cultural commissioner, who has known Cave for years.</p><p>Boone recalls a visit to the Randolph Street Market that revealed Cave’s way of seeing. She remembers passing a long wooden slab — “I think it was an African bed,” she says — and wondering aloud what anyone would ever do with it. An hour later, she saw Cave walking through the antique market with the piece tucked under his arm. When she later visited his home, the bed had become the centerpiece of his dining table. “It never would have occurred to me to see that as an art piece. The way Nick views the world is very, very different from most people.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-e80000" name="image-e80000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5cce36f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cba893f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a661045/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Nick Cave constructing one of his Woolly mammoths. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a661045/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ef4be10/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a661045/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5e%2F22%2Fee1a998e489bbdab59b9a2a485a3%2F240430-5830-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Cave stands inside an early, spectral prototype of one of his mammoths. He originally imagined them fully skinned.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of James Prinz Photography</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Cave is perhaps more like a bowerbird, collecting artifacts of daily life and assembling them into a world of his own making.</p><p>And like the forest bird’s elaborate nests, no object in Cave’s “Mammoth” is incidental. One, though, stands apart as a particular talisman: a walking cane that belonged to Cave’s youngest brother, Stacy, who died at 20. In the museum gallery, “it’s the first object you encounter,” explains Cave, who placed the cane in the show without altering it. “It was his cane. I didn’t need to do anything. It was everything it needed to be.”</p><p>The fact that his family’s relics are now on display at the Smithsonian simply amazes Cave. “My grandmother’s thimbles are in the Smithsonian,” he smiles. “That is American history.”</p><h3><b>An artist seizes the moment </b></h3><p>A week before “Mammoth” is set to open, Cave has just returned from Washington, D.C., where he finished installing the exhibition. A handful of studio assistants work studiously at their stations nearby. Cave employs ten full-time assistants, several of whom wore the mammoths for “Roam,” but that number can climb as high as 30 at the height of a project.</p><p>Today, the studio is quieter than it has been in months. Not only does “Mammoth” open as the Smithsonian sits at the center of the Trump administration’s anti-diversity campaign, but it also appears in a moment when stories of state violence dominate the headlines. That includes the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis, news that carries a grim echo of the early days of Cave’s career when he created his first Soundsuit.</p><p>Walking the studio floor, Cave pauses at a few mammoth heads that rest in a corner. He will eventually make a total of 13 mammoths — enough to form a herd — for a performance at the museum later this year. Looking at the pieces, Cave recalls the moment when the animal’s final form first came into focus.</p><p>Cave, who made the mammoths with the Chicago metal fabrication studio, Manifold, originally imagined the creatures fully skinned. But once he saw people standing beneath an early prototype, visible through the ribs, Cave changed his mind. “Something about that just revealed the state of the world today,” he says.</p><div data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“Nick has this unique ability to see beauty and art in things that people would otherwise be so quick to discard or not value,” says Michelle Boone, the president of the Poetry Foundation and former cultural commissioner.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Bringing this work to Washington now, adds Cave, only sharpens the stakes. The Smithsonian, Newman asserts, stands behind him. “The show is Nick’s vision,” she says. “We are presenting it. We will not change the show.”</p><p>The exhibition may have been nearly a decade in the making, but Cave believes the work is arriving in the world exactly when it’s meant to. “I believe I’m not ever given anything that I’m not supposed to have at any given moment,” reflects Cave. “So,” he adds, “I have a job to do.”</p><p><i>Elly Fishman’s reporting on news and culture has appeared in The New York Times, Rolling Stone, GQ, Fast Company, Chicago, and WBEZ, among others. She is currently working on her second book, forthcoming from HarperCollins.</i></p>
entries.author: Elly Fishman | WBEZ

entries.title: No recess, lockdowns, less learning: How immigration agents disrupted CPS schools this fall
entries.summary: <p>Alma’s 11-year-old boys had difficult questions for her after their school, Jungman Elementary in Pilsen, went on lockdown because federal immigration agents were nearby.</p><p>Her fifth graders remember being rushed back into their classrooms during dismissal on a day in late October as teachers ran out of the building to make sure no one was left outside. Afterwards, they wanted to know if it was safe to go back to school.</p><p>“I didn’t know what to say,” said Alma, who asked to be identified by only her first name because she is an immigrant and fears being targeted. “I told them that they are going to be safe inside the school, and they just have to be ready if it happens again.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c30000" name="image-c30000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6288414/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6772x3801+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F10%2F6e%2Ff3e425c541b9b2de9b5840b6c1e8%2Fcpslockdowns-260123-3.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A woman with long dark hair wearing a white sweater stands in shadow looking out the floor-to-ceiling windows of a building." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6288414/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6772x3801+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F10%2F6e%2Ff3e425c541b9b2de9b5840b6c1e8%2Fcpslockdowns-260123-3.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5e72a36/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6772x3801+0+357/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F10%2F6e%2Ff3e425c541b9b2de9b5840b6c1e8%2Fcpslockdowns-260123-3.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6288414/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6772x3801+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F10%2F6e%2Ff3e425c541b9b2de9b5840b6c1e8%2Fcpslockdowns-260123-3.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Alma is one of many Chicago Public Schools parents who fielded difficult questions from her children after federal immigration agents came near their school and disrupted dismissal.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Sun-Times Staff</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Alma has also prepared her twins in case a federal agent questions their American citizenship. If anyone asks where you’re from, she told them, you should answer that you were born in Chicago.</p><p>“I don’t think kids need to be going through this,” she said.</p><p>As President Donald Trump’s mass deportation campaign surged in Chicago last fall, Chicago Public Schools officials fielded an influx of calls for support from schools due to immigration enforcement activity near their buildings, records show.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-floatRight> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-000000" name="image-000000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3d0ec78/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ba4114d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7453ce9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Disrupted series logo updated" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7453ce9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0494f7f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7453ce9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+117/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F00%2F13%2Fdb09afd941d6ac444e0de11c2cab%2Fdisruptedlogo.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Eric White/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The presence of federal agents forced students inside during recess, canceled some after-school activities, disrupted learning and at times created chaos. Students, both from immigrant families and their peers, say the heightened environment left them looking over their shoulders and unable to concentrate on schoolwork, frequently glancing at classroom doors or worrying about family members.</p><p>It also placed an unprecedented burden on school principals and district officials, who had to ensure timely communication with families without sowing fear or spreading rumors. Community members say coordination with CPS was difficult at first and eventually improved, but the district still faces a big challenge if widespread enforcement returns.</p><p>“I don’t think we are where we need to be,” said Patrick Brosnan, executive director of the Brighton Park Neighborhood Council, a nonprofit on the Southwest Side that works closely with schools. He credits the school district for making adjustments to confront what he calls a “bananas” situation. At the same time, he said the school district and the city still needs to share information more freely and promptly.</p><p>“There is no blueprint for this, but we are going through it,” added Yesenia Lopez, a CPS board member whose heavily Latino district on the city’s Southwest Side has been a hotspot for enforcement operations. “Things keep escalating based on what we’ve seen out in other states and we're going to have to continue to act quickly as a district.”</p><h3>Widespread disruption when federal agents came near Chicago schools</h3><p>When Trump’s Chicago-area deportation campaign was at its peak last fall, schools reported federal immigration agents staging in school parking lots, showing up at elementary school soccer games, and detaining people on school grounds or where students could see them.</p><p>On Oct. 3, students had to stay inside when federal agents <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/10/09/funston-elementary-logan-square-school-tear-gas-johnson" target="_blank" ><u>threw tear gas on the street near Funston Elementary</u></a> in Logan Square.</p><p>Though the exact number of times federal activity disrupted schools isn’t known, it’s clear the effect was widespread. The Sun-Times and WBEZ compiled the most comprehensive accounting to date by reviewing district briefings for school board members and records of letters CPS sent to families informing them about federal activity near their schools.</p><p>CPS received nearly 200 calls for support from 109 schools between Oct. 20, when it opened a command center to centralize calls for assistance, through mid-December, according to CPS documents obtained through an open records request.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-190000" name="html-embed-module-190000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27483195"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27483195/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="chart visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>That’s likely an underestimate of how often agents came near schools, as principals often acted without reaching out to the central office and the command center launched more than a month into the deportation campaign.</p><p>CPS officials did not agree to an interview, but said in a statement that federal activity on school grounds is extremely rare and the district has mostly responded to reports of activity near school buildings. Over the last year, there have been no known instances of enforcement activity inside a CPS school.</p><p>Still, schools called the command center for help nearly every day in October and early November. On some days, CPS fielded dozens of calls.</p><p>For example, when federal agents flooded the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/immigration/2025/10/24/immigration-agents-arrest-lake-view-protest-tear-gas-west-town" target="_blank" ><u>North and Northwest sides on Oct. 24,</u></a> the command center got 37 calls from schools seeking help — the most recorded by the district this fall.</p><p>At least 10 schools thought the situation this fall posed enough of a safety risk to staff and students that they went on lockdown, according to a log of messages the district sent to parents. That means they kept students indoors and secured the doors.</p><p>North-Grand High School in Humboldt Park went on lockdown in early September after receiving reports of several suspected law enforcement vehicles in the parking lot of an adjacent shopping center. CPS officials couldn’t verify who the vehicles belonged to, but students assumed federal immigration agents were using them.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-1d0000" name="image-1d0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a8ef4cb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/983bf59/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6ec3b09/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A group of eight students wearing coats and backpacks walk in a line by a parking lot separated from the road by a black fence." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6ec3b09/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b89e645/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6ec3b09/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+58/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F20%2F45%2F998d0d6c4f8a88298eed661a193f%2Fcpslockdowns-260128-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>When suspected law enforcement vehicles showed up in a parking lot near North-Grand High School in Humboldt Park, the school went on lockdown. Some students are glad their schools take measures like this to keep them safe, but they can put children and teens in a state of high alert.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“A lot of kids were freaked out,” said Carrie, a 16-year-old student at North-Grand. We’re not using her real name because some of her family members are immigrants without legal status in the U.S.</p><p>That day the North-Grand junior sent panicked texts to her relatives, telling them to avoid the school. She started to cry when she didn’t get a response, worried that she’d sent the warning too late.</p><p>“I was texting my mother that I loved her so much,” she said.</p><p>After the lockdown, Carrie decided to stay home from school for a few days. Coming back meant working through her anxieties.</p><p>But the experience left a mark. She’s still on high alert while she’s in class.</p><p>“I look more at the door, I pay attention to who is at the doorway, who is leaving, who is in my classroom and who could be walking the halls,” Carrie said. “I memorized some of my friend’s footstep patterns.”</p><p>It’s not uncommon for fears about the presence of immigration agents to weigh heavily on children’s minds, psychologists say. They may become more emotional, distrust authority and have trouble sleeping.</p><p>“We may be asking them to take their history exam during the ninth period when their mind is worried about the commute home,” said Claudio Rivera, a pediatric psychologist and an assistant professor at the University of Chicago. “That’s not allowing them to focus on the learning opportunities that’s in front of them.”</p><p>The exact number of schools that went on lockdown during the fall is likely higher as the district doesn’t comprehensively track them.</p><p>In October, for example, Brosnan told Chalkbeat Chicago that <a class="Link" href="https://www.chalkbeat.org/chicago/2025/10/23/chicago-public-schools-board-members-want-virtual-learning-immigration/" target="_blank" ><u>about 30 schools on the Southwest Side</u></a> alone went on lockdown because of enforcement activity. Lopez, whose district includes Brighton Park, said that’s partly because federal agents frequently <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/09/27/tamale-vendor-arrested-back-of-the-yards-ice-immigration" target="_blank" ><u>stalked the Home Depot in neighboring Back of the Yards</u></a>, which is surrounded by several schools.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-900000" name="image-900000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fb706c0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/40e51f9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/395621e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A teen with long hair wearing a blue winter jacket stands outside her school with the lawn behind her covered in snow." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/395621e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/02a6fe5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/395621e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2Fa5%2F7b931de947e78ba7b153e723478c%2Fcpslockdowns-260205-01.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Julia Markut, a junior at Lane Tech High School, saw how the presence of federal immigration agents near her school affected her classmates’ mental health and made some students afraid to leave the building for lunch.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>At Lane Tech High School in the North Center neighborhood, junior Julia Markut said her peers were surprised when in October a loudspeaker message alerted them of federal immigration enforcement activity nearby. She watched in shock as one of her friends broke down in tears.</p><p>Her friend said: “I don’t know how I'll be able to get home, I have to call my parents,” Markut said. “It was sort of dehumanizing to see her experiencing that.”</p><p>Soon the loudspeaker alerts were coming multiple times a week, making the situation almost “normalized,” Markut said. The school started encouraging students, many of whom like to go out for lunch, to stay inside. It opened classrooms where students who are afraid to leave can find refuge.</p><p>But Julia thinks it shouldn't have to be this way.</p><p>“This fear shouldn't be incorporated into our routines,” she said.</p><p>The Department of Homeland Security did not respond to multiple requests to answer specific questions about federal activity around Chicago schools. The agency has said <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/09/19/suburban-parents-sound-alarm-on-immigration-enforcement-around-schools" target="_blank" ><u>its agents do not target schools</u></a>.</p><h3>Schools had to develop communications playbook around federal activity <b> </b></h3><p>The unpredictability of immigration enforcement actions made it difficult for CPS to figure out how and when to tell families about activity near schools.</p><p>Kia Banks, president of the Chicago Principals & Administrators Association, the union that represents CPS principals, said in the past schools initiated lockdowns following a set protocol, usually in response to something like a shooting, and coordinated with the Chicago Police Department and the school district.</p><p>But that protocol was turned on its head when federal agents repeatedly came near schools. Community organizations and schools were alerting CPS, rather than the other way around, and coordinating with the district to get communication out to parents could take hours. So, especially in the early days of the federal immigration operation, many Chicago principals made their own calls.</p><p>“There is no playbook for how to manage this level of an emergency,” Banks said. “You are burdened with the responsibility of protecting your school community and you do that any way you know how.”</p><p>Chris Graves, principal at Jordan Elementary School in Rogers Park, knows how that felt.</p><p>In his community, parents were finding out about immigration enforcement through their own networks or by listening to the whistles from neighborhood spotters. Waiting two hours to get permission from CPS to notify families about federal immigration agents in the area was too long, he said. He learned families preferred if the school acknowledged the situation in real time, even if it was to say that the sighting of agents was not confirmed.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-e00000" name="html-embed-module-e00000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-map" data-src="visualisation/27482980"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27482980/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="map visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>“That helped create a lot of sense of calm, because families saw that we were constantly messaging something,” Graves said.</p><p>The district eventually gave school leaders clearer guidance about how to handle immigration enforcement activity near their buildings. <a class="Link" href="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/78/b0/f53090534ffba3c272f450ff45e5/october-2025-cps-guidance.pdf" target="_blank" ><u>Introduced in October</u></a>, it instructs school leaders to bring students and staff inside and secure doors if federal activity is happening on the same block. If it's further away, they should monitor the activity. That’s something community members and rapid response teams can help with, Lopez noted.</p><p>School board members and principals say communication improved once schools had a single hotline to call and the district gave school leaders the go-ahead to use their own judgment to act quickly.</p><p>Steps like this have helped students like eighth grader Dennise Marioni at Gunsaulus Scholastic Academy. Parents said the Brighton Park school kept students indoors multiple times last fall, but Marioni said clear communication from the school kept her calm. In addition, staff often set up a perimeter around the school during dismissal or arrival to monitor for federal agents.</p><p>“They’re keeping us safe,” Marioni said.</p><p>CPS noted in a statement that <a class="Link" href="https://www.cps.edu/services-and-supports/new-presidential-administration-guidance/immigration-resources" target="_blank" ><u>district staff and school leaders worked</u></a> to “make rapid, real-time decisions in response to evolving conditions outside school campuses.” The district trained staff on how to respond to enforcement campaigns in the spring of 2025, and repeated the training in the fall when actions ramped up. CPS has also provided guidance to staff on what to do if a student’s parent or guardian is detained during the school day.</p><p>“The District acknowledges that these circumstances placed extraordinary demands on principals and central office staff, who worked diligently to keep students safe while also communicating accurately and responsibly with families,” a CPS spokesperson wrote in an email.</p><p>Lopez said while CPS did make great strides during an unprecedented event, the district could be more proactive in preparing for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/12/04/doj-lawyer-warns-midway-blitz-is-not-over-as-judge-considers-lawsuits-dismissal" target="_blank" ><u>possible return of widespread enforcement</u></a> in the spring.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-cd0000" name="image-cd0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/de71a4f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5998x3366+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8a%2F24%2F0f6be7d142adb725699600f9082f%2Fcommunitiesofcolor-111825-01.jpg alt="Yesenia Lopez November 2025 presser" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2c6ffab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5998x3366+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8a%2F24%2F0f6be7d142adb725699600f9082f%2Fcommunitiesofcolor-111825-01.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6d2717d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5998x3366+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8a%2F24%2F0f6be7d142adb725699600f9082f%2Fcommunitiesofcolor-111825-01.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2c6ffab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5998x3366+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8a%2F24%2F0f6be7d142adb725699600f9082f%2Fcommunitiesofcolor-111825-01.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>CPS Board member Yesenia Lopez has been outspoken about the need to support communities affected by Trump’s mass deportation campaign while preparing for a possible spring surge in enforcement.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>She and Brosnan would like to see the district temporarily expand the Safe Passage program, which helps students get to and from school safely, and make sure its command center hotline won’t crash if it receives more calls than in the fall.</p><p>Lopez would also like the district to seriously consider offering remote learning to students who are afraid to attend school during enforcement operations — something the district has said it would need <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/01/29/ctu-wants-to-bargain-with-cps-over-remote-learning-options" target="_blank" ><u>state approval to do</u></a>.</p><p>There is a renewed sense of urgency to make sure schools feel prepared after escalating events in Minnesota last month. There, federal agents detained a 5-year-old boy <a class="Link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/30/us/valley-view-elementary-minnesota-children-ice-detention.html" target="_blank" ><u>on the way home from school</u></a> and deployed chemical irritants and tackled several people <a class="Link" href="https://www.mprnews.org/story/2026/01/08/after-border-patrol-clash-at-roosevelt-minneapolis-schools-cancel-classes" target="_blank" ><u>at a high school</u></a> in south Minneapolis. Closer to home, masked federal agents scanned the face of a 16-year-old outside an Aurora high school, <a class="Link" href="https://illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/News-Room/Current-News/001%20-%20Complaint%201.12.26.pdf?language_id=1" target="_blank" ><u>according to court records</u></a>, which can give agents access to sensitive personal information.</p><p>The Trump administration also has told federal agents that they have broad powers to arrest people without warrants and <a class="Link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/30/us/politics/ice-expands-power-agents-warrants.html" target="_blank" ><u>enter homes with a warrant that hasn’t been signed by a judge.</u></a> That’s left Chicago principals wanting more guidance from the district if federal agents apply that logic to schools.</p><p>Mary Urban, a special education teacher at North-Grand High School, said teachers have tried not to let the situation affect their classrooms, but it’s been difficult to ignore. Urban was teaching a unit on the U.S. Constitution in the fall when immigration enforcement ramped up.</p><p>“Every time we would look at the Bill of Rights, there was a question mark, saying, ‘Well, but do I really have these rights?’” Urban said. “There was this sense of sadness, of trauma, but also injustice because young people understand what's happening in the world around them.”</p><bsp-list-loadmore data-module class="PageListD" data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-hide-descriptions="true" data-hide-reading-time="true" ><a entries.title: Plans are underway to get rid of Cook County’s property tax sales in the coming years
entries.summary: <p>Plans are underway to sunset Cook County’s contentious property tax sale system in the coming years.</p><p>Last week, state Sen. Celina Villanueva filed a bill to bring Illinois into compliance with a 2023 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that deemed it unconstitutional for property owners to lose the surplus equity they are entitled to once their property has been foreclosed due to delinquent taxes and after the debt has been paid.</p><p>Villanueva did not immediately respond to requests for comment.</p><p>Under the current system, if property taxes are unpaid, Illinois law allows counties to sell those tax certificates at an annual tax sale to recoup the revenue they hoped to get from property taxes. Investors, or tax buyers, buy the certificates, and tack on fees and interest that property owners must redeem, or pay, in order to keep their property. </p><p>If property owners don’t pay within two-and-a-half to three years, tax buyers can go to court and pursue the deed of the property to make back what they paid. That’s where the issue lies. Properties could have equity far greater than the amount of the delinquent taxes, and the courts have ruled that property owners are entitled to it, according to the United States Constitution. But with the way things are now, investors get that equity after a tax foreclosure because they possess the deed. Property owners often have to vacate the property.</p><p>Under the new system, in lieu of a tax sale, property owners will still have three years to settle their property tax debt. However, if they haven’t by that time, “the county would have to petition the court for a tax deed, and that property would get looped through a foreclosure auction to the highest bidder,” according to Justin Kirvan, the policy director in the Cook County Treasurer’s office.</p><p>Everyone, including the property owners, can bid in the auction. The minimum bid would be set at the amount of the delinquent taxes owed to the county, Kirvan said.</p><p>The legislation is powered by a coalition of housing advocates called the Tyler v. Hennepin Coalition, to lead the charge of ensuring that Illinois complied with a Supreme Court ruling under that same case. The group includes the Cook County Treasurer’s Office, the Cook County President’s Office, the Chicago Community Trust, Housing Action Illinois, Neighborhood Housing Services, and AARP.</p><p>“This legislation, at minimum, will have protections in place for folks who are the most vulnerable to ensure their equity is still protected in a tax sale,” said Torrence Gardener, manager of policy change at the Chicago Community Trust. “Justice is definitely needed at this time.”</p><p>Illinois is the only state that has not yet formally changed its property tax sale rules to align with the Supreme Court ruling, according to Kirvan. And there have been consequences. In a December 2025 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/12/10/cook-county-homeowners-property-tax-sales-foreclosures-illegal-federal-judge" target="_blank" ><u>ruling</u></a> of Kidd v. Pappas, U.S. District Judge Matthew F. Kennelly issued a summary judgment that Cook County’s “tax sale procedures violate the Fifth and Eighth Amendments” of the United States Constitution. The case is a class-action lawsuit starting with a west suburban Maywood homeowner who lost her home in a tax foreclosure sale, and did not receive the surplus equity that was owed to her.</p><p>SB 3940 will effectively impact the investors’ interest in the tax sales, and Kirvan believes they may not favor the legislation.</p><p>“I think tax buyers would view this remedy as impacting their profits negatively because they won’t be able to take tax deeds free and clear with any equity that comes with the deed any longer under this legislation,” Kirvan said.</p><p>In a statement from the Illinois Tax Purchasers Association, the group said it recognizes “the ongoing discussion around potential changes to Illinois law following Tyler v. Hennepin County and looks forward to continuing to work with Senator Villanueva, Representative Tarver, and other stakeholders on thoughtful, workable solutions.”</p><p>State Rep. Curtis Tarver is the chairperson of the Illinois House Revenue & Finance Committee.</p><p>The December judgment for Kidd v. Pappas suggests that counties could be on the hook to pay the surplus equity owed to property owners. Experts say the tax auction is the best play for Cook County to “protect themselves against future liability,” according to Matt Kriese, general counsel for the Center for Community Progress, a national nonprofit that helps restore vacant and abandoned properties to productive use in communities. However, Kriese said that the county should “have a robust series of tools to be able to keep [property owners] out of [the tax sale] pipeline.”</p><p>“The fact that somebody could lose their home because they’re unable to pay their property taxes is a terrible outcome that we want to do everything in our power, I think, to prevent,” Kriese added.</p><p>While the legislation makes its way to the floor, there is still the issue of this spring’s anticipated tax sale. Last year, when Springfield legislators filed proposals to make the state’s tax sale system compliant with the Supreme Court ruling, they also postponed last year’s tax sale until March 2026. However, even if the legislature swiftly passes this bill, the county's tax offices and courts will need time to implement the new rules, according to Kirvan.</p><p>Kirvan’s position is that the March 2026 tax sale must be postponed. “We are doing all we can to persuade the General Assembly to amend the statute that currently requires the sale to be held in March,” he said.</p><p>While the bill will address some immediate needs, the road to reform continues. On Feb. 25, the Supreme Court will hear another case about a central Michigan property that was sold in a foreclosure auction due to delinquent property taxes. In Peng v. Isabella County, the plaintiffs argue that the surplus equity they received after the auction sale was less than the equity they were due based on the value of the home.</p><p>In response, Kirvan said, “our read of that is that in the foreclosure context, the winning bid at an auction like this is a court-sanctioned way of determining the fair market value of the property again within the foreclosure context.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/12/10/cook-county-homeowners-property-tax-sales-foreclosures-illegal-federal-judge" >Property tax foreclosures illegally stripped Cook County homeowners of their equity, federal judge rules</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/05/16/tax-foreclosures-illinois-home-ownership-velma-lewis-cook-county" >Illinois is the last state still unlawfully stripping wealth from homeowners in tax foreclosures</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/11/17/cook-county-property-taxes-analysis-treasurer-maria-pappas-downtown-south-west-sides" >Black neighborhoods hit hardest with Cook County property tax bill increase, analysis finds</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/06/06/property-tax-foreclosure-reform-illinois-legislature-maria-pappas" >Property tax foreclosure reform is put off by Illinois legislators</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Nicole Jeanine Johnson

entries.title: DuSable Black History Museum gets $1.6 million Illinois grant for building improvements
entries.summary: <p>The DuSable Black History Museum and Education Center will receive a $1.6 million state grant for renovations. The first installment was presented earlier this month in a check by Illinois Comptroller Susana Mendoza.</p><p>The funds will go to updating bathrooms, the museum’s Harold Washington wing, and the theater, said CEO Perri Irmer at a <a class="Link" href="https://www.facebook.com/watch/live/?ref=watch_permalink&v=1215131217407778" target="_blank" ><u>press </u></a>event. The improvements made to the wing and theater will allow the museum to increase revenue via facility rentals, she said.</p><p>The state funds and renovation plans come as Black History Month is underway, and the museum extends its February hours of operation to seven days a week.</p><p>“I want to be able to welcome folks back to a rejuvenated museum as we enter our 65th year,” Irmer said. “That's really amazing, as the oldest Black history museum in the country, and at … such a critical time when our history and our people are under attack.”</p><div class="Enhancement" The current exhibition is “Paris in Black.” </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The Trump administration’s move to cancel some grants awarded through the National Endowment for the Arts and end federal diversity, equity and inclusion programs has disrupted American museums, including the DuSable in Chicago and beyond. According to a November report by<a class="Link" href="https://www.aam-us.org/2025/11/11/national-survey-reveals-alarming-downturn-museums-face-worst-financial-outlook-since-pandemic/" target="_blank" ><u> the American Alliance of Museums,</u></a> a third of U.S. museums have lost government grants or contracts.</p><p>The DuSable has struggled with funding and staff turnover in recent years.<b> </b>In<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/museums-zoos/2025/12/02/dusable-black-history-museum-chicago-director-kim-dulaney-whistleblower-lawsuit-perri-irmer" target="_blank" ><u> a whistleblower lawsuit</u></a> filed early December in the Circuit Court of Cook County, a former employee raised numerous questions about the museum’s financial and organizational stability. </p><p>The lawsuit filed in December by Kim Dulaney, a retired Chicago State University professor who joined the South Side museum staff in 2021, alleges that she was fired as retaliation for “questioning DuSable’s irregular fiscal practices.”</p><p>Several former employees, associates and observers told the Sun-Times they’ve known about issues at the museum for years — and Dulaney is far from the first person to raise them.</p><p>Previous attempts to reach Irmer to comment on the lawsuit were unsuccessful. Approached by a reporter at the check presentation ceremony, Irmer said that while she won’t comment on pending litigation, “We're going to tell our positive story. Every business has disgruntled employees that don't like being terminated.”</p><p>And with the Obama Presidential Center set to open in June just a mile east of the museum, Irmer wants the DuSable to be a part of the influx of visitors to the neighborhood. “That's another reason why it's so important for us to present a modernized, well-maintained face for all of the visitors that are going to be coming from around the world,” Irmer said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-270000"
