alt="Visitors peruse the exhibition "Paris In Black" at the DuSable Museum. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ab51aa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6756x3792+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F3b%2F4f07829d4d73af24e5f4d955d4b2%2Fparisblack-112325-021.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6af8a8a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6756x3792+0+357/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F3b%2F4f07829d4d73af24e5f4d955d4b2%2Fparisblack-112325-021.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ab51aa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6756x3792+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F3b%2F4f07829d4d73af24e5f4d955d4b2%2Fparisblack-112325-021.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Visitors peruse the exhibition “Paris In Black” at the DuSable Museum. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“The museum has always been under-resourced,” she said. “I'm not sure where they would be” without the taxpayer money it receives from being located in the park district, Dickerson added.</p><p>And despite the museum’s history, it has never been accredited by the American Alliance of Museums. Sources close to the DuSable Museum’s Board of Trustees told a reporter there is a lot of confusion about the museum’s accreditation status and collections care, some incorrectly believing that the institution has been accredited all along.</p><p>Asked at the check presentation ceremony about Dulaney’s lawsuit, Mendoza said: “I don't know any facts about it, really zero. But my contribution is in making sure that museums like this get funded.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-f60000" name="html-embed-module-f60000"></a><iframe src="https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?height=314&href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FILComptroller%2Fvideos%2F1215131217407778%2F&show_text=false&width=560&t=0" width="560" height="314" style="border:none;overflow:hidden" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true" allow="autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowFullScreen="true"></iframe> </div> </div><p>Dulaney’s complaint prompted an investigation by the Chicago Park District Office of Inspector General. In December, the park district, which is the museum’s landlord, said in a statement that it forwarded Dulaney’s complaint to its Office of Inspector General, which is currently conducting its investigation.</p><p>“We expect that our cultural partners will abide by all applicable laws and best practices,” the park district’s statement read.</p><p>The OIG’s office declined to provide further comment, and there is no timeline for the investigation’s completion.</p><p>At the first hearing in Dulaney’s case, held last week at the Circuit Court of Cook County building, lawyers for the DuSable Museum said an internal investigation into the matter was underway.</p><p>When the DuSable Black History Museum and Education opened in 1961, it put Chicago on the map as home to the nation’s first independent museum of Black history.</p><p>Chicago’s DuSable Black History Museum and Education Center was founded in 1961 by six co-founders, including Dr. Margaret T. Burroughs, who was known as a powerhouse artist and educator who had an outsized influence on Chicago’s South Side.</p><p>The idea for the museum was born in the living room of Burroughs’ Bronzeville mansion, which she shared with her husband, Charles. Together, they started the Ebony Museum of Negro History because they were worried about the erasure of Black history in the U.S.</p><p>Those close to her said she was a champion of the community and often welcomed homeless Black artists and creatives into her mansion with open arms. Dr. Burroughs died in 2010 at 95.</p><p>Today, the DuSable Museum holds more than 15,000 pieces of art and artifacts.</p>
entries.author: Ambar Colón

entries.title: What to know about Chicago's delivery robots and the debate over them
entries.summary: <p>When Lincoln Park resident Ainsley Harris first spotted a delivery robot in her neighborhood last year, she said it wasn’t the technology that caught her attention. It was the look.</p><p>The boxy, pink and orange robot felt more playful than mechanical, Harris said. Even “kind of cute.” It was one of a fleet of robots belonging to Coco Robotics, a Los Angeles-based sidewalk delivery company, that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/technology/2025/01/14/coco-delivery-robot-chicago" >began appearing in some Chicago neighborhoods in late 2024. </a></p><p>But things changed for her when robot operations began to ramp up in Lincoln Park, she said. A mother of two, Harris is responsible for a stroller, a labradoodle and a young kid on a bike when she goes out for walks. More robots on her neighborhood's narrow sidewalks mean she has to be even more aware to ensure their safety.</p><p>"The more time that I spent with them, and the more close contact I had with them...the more I began to kind of sour on them and having them in the neighborhood," Harris, 42, said. </p><p>Harris isn't alone in her sentiment. Josh Robertson, one of Harris' neighbors, <a class="Link" href="https://nosidewalkbots.org/" target="_blank" >started a petition</a> last summer to call on the city to pause the sidewalk robot program until they release safety findings on the devices and set rules for how they're deployed. The petition has received over 3,400 signatures from more than 50 ZIP codes across the city. </p><p>"Sidewalks are for people, and should remain people-first," Robertson, 40, said. </p><p>As companies push to dispatch more of the delivery robots across neighborhoods in Chicago, Robertson said he hopes his petition will place pressure on city officials to pause the services. </p><p>Here's an overview of the current state of robot delivery in the city — and how Chicagoans are responding. </p><h3>What companies are behind Chicago’s delivery robots?</h3><p>Coco Robotics and Serve Robotics are the two tech companies that have rolled out delivery robots across the city in the last two years.</p><p>Coco's robots began appearing in the 27th and 34th wards as part of its initial pilot program. Serve Robotics, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/business/2025/09/29/look-out-coco-the-food-delivery-robots-introduced-in-late-2024-now-have-competition" target="_blank" >another Los Angeles-based sidewalk robotics company</a>, launched 50 robots across much of the city's North and West sides last September, adding to the growing fleet of robotic delivery couriers. </p><p>The robots were first allowed by the city in 2022, when then-Mayor Lori Lightfoot announced that the City Council had approved of a Personal Delivery Device (PDD) pilot program. This program allowed for local food establishments to partner with the companies to use their small robots to deliver food to their customers. Throughout the launch of the program, the Chicago Department of Transportation carried out an assessment of the robots to see if they can be used safely without inconveniencing sidewalk users.</p><p>The program is still ongoing and will not renew past May 2027 without action from the City Council, according to the city's website. In December, <a class="Link" href="https://311.chicago.gov/s/article/Personal-Delivery-Devices-PDD?language=en_US" target="_blank" >the city released a 311 category</a> to encourage Chicago residents to submit their concerns and feedback about the robots.</p><h3>Where in the city can you run into a delivery robot?</h3><p>There are currently 100 delivery robots up and running in the city.</p><p>Coco's 50 robots operate in Fulton Market, the West Loop, River West, the Loop, South Loop and Greektown.</p><p>Serve's 50 robots operate in 14 neighborhoods: Austin, Belmont Cragin, Dunning, East Garfield Park, Humboldt Park, Lake View, Lincoln Park, Little Italy, Logan Square, Near North Side, Near West Side, Uptown, West Garfield Park and West Town.</p><p>Notably, neither company's robots operate on the city's South side.</p><h3>Do they deliver anything other than food?</h3><p>Both Serve and Coco have partnerships with Uber Eats for food and restaurant deliveries.</p><p>Coco robots also supports delivery for certain grocery and everyday essentials through its partnership with DoorDash and DashMart, according to a representative for Coco robots. Serve's director of government affairs, Yariel Diaz, said the company hopes to expand "beyond food delivery to groceries, medications, parcels and more."</p><p>Customers in the neighborhoods where robot delivery is available are able to choose their preferred delivery method when placing an order in their app of choice. Users can also opt out of robot delivery entirely.</p><h3>Do they accept tips?</h3><p>No. Robots don't accept tips.</p><h3>Can the robots deal with snow and ice?</h3><p>Both companies say their robots are equipped to operate in winter conditions, but <a class="Link" href="https://www.youtube.com/shorts/NGIR5it1gSE" target="_blank" >one city resident documented</a> a robot getting stuck in the snow this winter. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-520000" name="image-520000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ee9d680/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2881094/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f8173ec/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="DH1_2469-2.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f8173ec/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3a2df73/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f8173ec/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4256x2389+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F22%2F13%2F685ea1e941eb816bb16eb28eb4b8%2Fdh1-2469-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A Serve Robotics food delivery robot goes on a test run downtown earlier this month.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>How have residents and alderpersons responded to the robots?</h3><p>Several alderpersons across the city have begun surveying their residents to gauge interest in expanding robot services into their neighborhoods. </p><p>Alderman Bennett Lawson (44th) and Alderwoman Angela Clay (46th) sent out surveys to their respective constituents in November. Alderman Daniel La Spata (1st) hosted a virtual meeting with representatives from both robot companies and constituents on Feb. 2 to provide residents in his ward with an opportunity to ask questions and share concerns. In addition to the meeting, his offices also collected feedback. </p><p>In a statement released Tuesday, his office said that robot deliveries will not be expanding further in the ward after 83.7% of 1st Ward respondents strongly disagreed with the expansion.</p><p>"While I will not be asking Coco to pull back from their limited pilot area east of Wood Street, neither company will be expanding further into the ward," he said in the statement.</p><p>Since starting his petition, Robertson said he's added an optional incident field where people can leave their experiences with the robots. He said he has seen around 850 incident reports on his form, as individuals reported incidents of collisions, injuries and obstruction of sidewalks around their neighborhoods.</p><p>"These robots have had a real tangible effect for Chicagoans going about their lives at street and sidewalk levels," Robertson said.</p><h3>What do delivery drivers and couriers think?</h3><p>Efrain Berrocal, a courier and dispatch coordinator at Chicago-based Cut Cats, a courier service run by cyclists, said the robots may pose a threat to traditional courier services.</p><p>"We haven't seen it be an issue so far, but I could see it becoming an issue when, inevitably, restaurants start to use more 3rd party apps, and then those 3rd party apps start to get their own robots," he said. "Then...we might see an issue."</p><p>To combat this, the 12-year-old business that has worked with over 85 restaurants and businesses in the city, continues to market itself as a local group, where humans are part of the entire process.</p><p>But both Coco and Serve argue that the robots are a boon both for businesses and human couriers.</p><p>In a statement, a Coco representative said that Chicago is well suited for short-distance deliveries because of the city's density and walkability. </p><p>"For restaurants and retailers, robots help make last-mile delivery more efficient by reducing congestion, lowering delivery costs, and smoothing peak demand, especially during busy meal times," the representative said. </p><p>According to Serve's website, when the robots focus on short-distance delivery, "human couriers are able to focus on higher-value deliveries and restaurants can stay focused on cooking and in-store guests." </p><p>The website also says that servicing the robot operations also creates new roles in remote assistance, fleet operations and maintenance. "Robots act as a supplemental tool alongside human workers, not a replacement," the website said.</p><h3>Which is faster — a robot or a human?</h3><p>A representative for Coco robots said: "Robot delivery isn't designed to compete on raw speed. The bigger goal is easing congestion in cities by taking short car trips off the road. Coco robots move at pedestrian pace, up to about 5 mph, and intentionally slow down around people or obstacles. The focus is efficiency, not rushing, helping complete short delivery trips in a predictable, low-impact way while reducing traffic and emissions," in a statement sent via email.</p><p>According to Serve robots website, their average delivery time is about 18 minutes.</p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: Developer unveils 40-unit affordable apartment building in Humboldt Park
entries.summary: <p>The Hispanic Housing Development Corp. celebrated the opening of an affordable apartment project in Humboldt Park on Wednesday, answering the community’s call for more family-sized units in the rapidly gentrifying neighborhood.</p><p>“These affordable apartments are going to enable 40 families to continue to call Humboldt Park home,” Hispanic Housing Development Corp. CEO Tony Hernandez said.</p><p>The project, at 1237 N. California Ave. across from Humboldt Park, is the second development the Hispanic Housing Development Corp. has recently opened in the West Side. The Pedro Albizu Campos Apartments, 1203 N. California Ave., opened in May 2024 with 64 affordable apartments. There's currently a waitlist for three-bedroom units at the Pedro Albizu Campos, according to the Hispanic Housing Development’s website.</p><p>Hernandez said the two projects — with more to come — represent “a bulwark against the forces of gentrification that are displacing families from the community.” </p><p>The developer purchased the site at 1237 N. California from the Puerto Rican Parade Committee in 2019 for just over $1 million, property records show. </p><p>The previous building “had fallen into disrepair,” Hernandez said, leading the company to respond to community calls to purchase and redevelop the site. Demolition took place soon after, and project partners broke ground on the cleared land in July 2024.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-550000" name="image-550000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/64e7d6f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0745c79/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a49d8d2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Hispanic Housing Development Corp. CEO Tony Hernandez" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a49d8d2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c7aa6d8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a49d8d2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5431x3048+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F58%2F04094dae4d2b894b8d644bb84c96%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Hispanic Housing Development Corp. CEO Tony Hernandez</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The six-story building has 10 one-bedroom units, 25 two-bedroom apartments and five three-bedroom units. And 18 units are eligible for housing voucher recipients, supported by the Chicago Housing Authority. The property also has a community room, indoor bicycle storage and laundry facility.</p><p>The larger apartments follow community calls for more family-sized units in the neighborhood, as westward development spreading to Humboldt Park raises rents and pushes long-time families out of the area. </p><p>Monthly rents at the new building range from $900 to $1,800, according to the project team. A two-bedroom apartment rents between $1,120 to $1,450.</p><p>The building is already fully leased — a sign of strong demand for affordable apartments in the neighborhood.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-f40000" name="image-f40000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1443d70/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/93e45d8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/81d33ca/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="View of Humboldt Park from inside a two-bedroom apartment at 1237 N. California Ave." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/81d33ca/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b7e955a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/81d33ca/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+519/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fea%2F1c%2F2276f3854e659960803613b9c78b%2Fhumboldthouse-260212-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>View of Humboldt Park from a two-bedroom apartment at 1237 N. California Ave.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“It’s no secret Humboldt Park is one of the fastest gentrifying neighborhoods in the city of Chicago,” Ald. Jessie Fuentes (26th) said during the project's ribbon cutting ceremony. “When we think about projects like this, we dream of a community where neighborhoods don't have to say goodbye to their childhood memories, or where children don't have to grow up in a neighborhood that their parents do not have ties in.”</p><p>Nearly half of all Humboldt Park renters experience housing cost burdens, according to Heather Spray, who manages multifamily development for the Illinois Housing Development Authority. Nearly a third of residents spend more than half of their income on rent. Experts say renters should typically spend about one-third of their monthly income on rent.</p><p>“On a personal level, this means that residents may be forced to sacrifice money for food, health care and other necessities to keep their housing. On a community level, long-time residents move out of the area,” Spray said. “We want to prevent both from happening.”</p><p>The city of Chicago provided the bulk of the funding for the $32 million project, with a grant from IHDA helping to bridge the remaining funding gap. Merchants Capital, Freddie Mac and ComEd also supported the project.</p><p>Jose Lopez, executive director of the Puerto Rican Cultural Center, said the building's design is significant — something that can often be overlooked in affordable housing. The coquí, a frog native to Puerto Rico, is featured in the building's artwork. A coquí pin was also worn by project partners during the ribbon cutting. </p><p>“It's a very small toad that makes an amazingly beautiful song at night,” Lopez said. “For Puerto Ricans, it’s a very beloved, beloved symbol of who we are. Human beings are aesthetics and creative beings. And for us, where we live should reflect that.”</p><p>The Hispanic Housing Development has "big plans" for the future of the Northwest Side, Hernandez said. </p><p>The developer broke ground in January on the redevelopment of the historic <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/07/14/humboldt-park-historic-pioneer-arcade-redeveloped-affordable-senior-housing" >Pioneer Arcade building</a> in Humboldt Park, which will be converted into 61 affordable senior housing units. The developer is also partnering with the Puerto Rican Cultural Center to develop two affordable housing buildings near Division Street and Western Avenue. One of the buildings will be senior housing, while the other targets families. </p>
entries.author: Abby Miller

entries.title: How immigration agents disrupted CPS schools
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: For Chicago's public school students, last fall was defined by no recess, distressing lockdowns, less learning and more anxiety as the Trump administration carried out its mass deportation campaign.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: City Council's budget rebellion, a Fat Thursday ode to Polish Pączki Cafe and more news you need to know.</p><p>📝 <b>Keeping score</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-y/" target="_blank" >The Bulls fell to the Celtics</a>, 124-105.</p><p>📧 <b>Subscribe</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletter-hub.suntimes.com/" target="_blank" >Get this newsletter delivered to your inbox weekday mornings.</a></p><p>⏱️: <i>An 8-minute read</i></p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S WEATHER 🌥️</h4><p>Partly cloudy with a high near 40.</p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S TOP STORY 🔎</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Chicago Public Schools fielded nearly 200 calls for assistance last fall when federal immigration agents came near schools.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-t/" target="_blank" >How immigration agents disrupted CPS schools</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-i/" target="_blank" >Emmanuel Camarillo</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-d/" target="_blank" >Sarah Karp</a></h5><p><b>ICE and education</b>: As President Donald Trump’s mass deportation campaign surged in Chicago last fall, Chicago Public Schools officials fielded an influx of calls for support from schools due to immigration enforcement activity near their buildings, records show.</p><p><b>The impact</b>: The presence of federal agents forced students inside during recess and after-school activities, disrupted learning, and at times created chaos. Students, both those from immigrant families and their peers, say the heightened environment left them looking over their shoulders and unable to concentrate, frequently glancing at classroom doors or worrying about family members.</p><p><b>CPS' role</b>: It also placed an unprecedented burden on school principals and district officials, who had to ensure timely communication with families without sowing fear or spreading rumors. Community members say coordination with CPS was difficult at first and eventually improved, but the district still faces a big challenge if widespread enforcement returns.</p><p><b>Key quote</b>: Educators say they've tried not to let the situation affect their classrooms, but it's difficult to ignore. "Every time we would look at the Bill of Rights, there was a question mark, saying, 'Well, but do I really have these rights?'" said Mary Urban, a special education teacher in Humboldt Park. "There was this sense of sadness, of trauma, but also injustice because young people understand what’s happening in the world around them."</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-h/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>IMMIGRATION ✶</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-2d0000" name="image-2d0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5f29567/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0597672/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89481cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Marimar Martinez (left) and her attorney Christopher Parente (right) during a press conference in the Loop on Feb. 11, 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89481cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ed75ca9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89481cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa0%2Fc0%2F4b445cb045d6b3dff8a6a7b17fba%2F186a4429.jpg" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Marimar Martinez sits next to her attorney Chris Parente on Wednesday.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-k/" target="_blank" >DHS says Border Patrol agent was ‘placed on administrative leave’ after shooting Chicago woman</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-u/" target="_blank" >Jon Seidel</a></h5><p><b>'Big time' support</b>: Charles Exum, the U.S. Border Patrol agent who shot and wounded Chicago’s Marimar Martinez, once wrote that his superiors had been supportive of him "big time." Border Patrol Cmdr. Gregory Bovino praised him after the shooting. Support continued up the chain, Exum said, from U.S. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem to someone known as "El Jefe himself" — who might be President Donald Trump.</p><p><b>Pointing to evidence</b>: Martinez and her attorneys say newly released evidence shows Exum lied to justify the shooting. A U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesperson said Wednesday that Exum "was placed on administrative leave."</p><p><b>Key context</b>: While incremental, the notable development comes after a weekslong campaign by Martinez, who was shot five times Oct. 4 on the Southwest Side. Martinez decided to speak out last month after immigration officers in Minneapolis fatally shot Renee Macklin Good and Alex Pretti.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-o/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p> </p><h4>EDUCATION 🍎</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-b50000" name="image-b50000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/164fd50/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/baa3766/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b9a35fe/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="The front of ASPIRA Business and Finance High School in Chicago's Avondale neighborhood. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b9a35fe/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dc64350/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b9a35fe/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6877x3860+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F46%2F0c%2F264748734e3e9d77587042985785%2Faspira-111925-5.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>ASPIRA Business and Finance High School in Avondale on the Northwest Side is one of two campuses run by the charter school that is at risk of closing.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-b/" target="_blank" >CPS charter school faces insolvency by March</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-n/" target="_blank" >Sarah Karp</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-p/" target="_blank" >Emmanuel Camarillo</a></h5><p><b>Uncertain future</b>: The majority of Chicago school board members seem prepared to allow the Aspira charter school network, in financial distress, to close midyear — which would leave more than 570 students in two high schools in a precarious position.</p><p><b>March deadline</b>: Board members say they are not inclined to save the network, which has informed the school district that it needs $4.8 million from CPS to stay open through the end of the school year. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-v/" target="_blank" >1 in 4 Chicago adults live with disability, report says</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-e/" target="_blank" >Kade Heather</a></h5><p><b>City report</b>: One in four Chicago adults are living with a disability, and the majority reside on the South and West sides, according to a new report released Tuesday by the city. </p><p><b>Key context</b>: The report uncovers for the first time key information about the city’s population of people with disabilities and inequities in their neighborhoods, laying the groundwork for the city to improve those conditions. The data was collected from a 2024 survey of Chicagoans conducted by the city's health department. </p><p><b>Key findings</b>: Black residents make up a plurality of Chicago’s disability population at about 32%, followed by Latinos at 27%. Asian and white residents each make up about 20%, the report found. Cognitive and mobility issues were the most common types of disabilities reported in Chicago adults.</p><p><a class="Link" Robin Kelly’s decision to launch a bid to replace outgoing Sen. Dick Durbin set up a contentious 10-person open race in the 2nd Congressional District Democratic primary, including a political comeback attempt by former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr.</p><p><b>Who's running</b>: Cook County Commissioner Donna Miller is leading fundraising in the crowded field. State Sen. Robert Peters (D-Chicago) has the progressive backing, including a glowing endorsement from U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders. Rounding out the field are state Sen. Willie Preston; Metropolitan Water Reclamation District Board member Yumeka Brown; Adal Regis, who worked in Kelly’s district office; management consultant Eric France; attorney Patrick "PJK" Keating; Toni C. Brown; Jackson; and Sidney Moore.</p><p><b>Their back stories</b>: One candidate was appointed to the state Senate as now-state Attorney General Kwame Raoul's successor, another is serving her second term on the Cook County Board — and a third previously represented this district and faced federal charges for misusing campaign funds.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-jr/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>FROM THE PRESS BOX 🏈⚾🏀🤼</h4><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-c81baf01-081c-11f1-8ff7-ab24675b365c"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-jy/" target="_blank" ><b>NFL mock draft</b></a>: The Super Bowl is over and the NFL Scouting Combine takes place at the end of the month. data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Polish Pączki Cafe owners Anna Niziolek (left) and Bozena Zakrzewski make pączki at Polish Paczki Cafe in Norwood Park. The two friends decided they “had to do something” after a longtime Polish restaurant closed in 2018 and opened Polish Pączki Cafe.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-tl/" target="_blank" >At Polish Pączki Cafe, tradition is the secret ingredient</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-tr/" target="_blank" >Joanna Marszałek</a></h5><p>It is 10 a.m. on a recent Saturday, and at Polish Pączki Cafe on the Northwest Side, a line starts to form at the counter. Customers just say "10," "six," "12," and there’s no need for explanation. Although the unassuming place, located in a strip mall, serves a variety of savory dishes, the namesake pączki are the star.</p><p>Poles in Chicago and in Poland eat pączki throughout the year, with many bakeries, delis and supermarkets offering a variety of fillings and glazes. But the real celebration is on Tłusty Czwartek (Fat Thursday), which precedes America’s Pączki Day (Fat Tuesday), and is traditionally a time to consume all fats and sugar before Lent.</p><p>At Polish Pączki Cafe, 7210 W. Foster Ave., every now and then a customer unfamiliar with the classic Polish delicacy walks in, lured by the activity inside and the boxes others carry out. If co-owner Anna Niziołek is around, she will educate newcomers on the pronunciation ("two PAWNCH-key but one PAWN-chek"), the origins and the process of making pączki.</p><p>She will gently correct those who call her pączki "doughnuts" and is quick to explain that they don’t sell them with custard, chocolate or other fillings. The original filling — a mix of plum, rose and raspberry marmalades imported from Poland — is hand-folded into the dough before frying, rather than injected afterward.</p><p>"Our pączki are special because we make them fresh every day from scratch by hand, using a very old Polish recipe," Niziołek said.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-ty/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>YOUR DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><p><b>What's the best way to spend Valentine's Day in Chicago if you're single? ❤️</b></p><p><a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" ><i>Email us</i></a><i> with your answer (please include your first and last name). We may run your answer in a future newsletter or story.</i></p><p>Yesterday, we asked you: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-tt/" target="_blank" >What’s your favorite work of art that you’ve seen at Chicago’s museums?</a></p><p>Here’s some of what you said…</p><p>"Edward Hopper’s 'Nighthawks.' A few lonely people late at night in a diner — it makes me wonder how many of us who’ve been that lonely at some point have seen ourselves in that Art Institute masterwork." — <i>Paul Lockwood</i></p><p>"'Paris Street on a Rainy Day,' 1877, by the French artist Gustave Caillebotte, [which] hangs in the Art Institute collection. It’s so lifelike, it feels as if you could reach out and shake hands with the couple in the foreground." — <i>Russell Bath</i></p><p>"The Marc Chagall stained glass windows [at the Art Intitute] has always been one of my favorites." — <i>Laura Pergola</i></p><p>"My favorite exhibited work is 'Judith Slaying Holofernes' by Artemisia Gentileschi. The painting shows a Biblical scene, unusual for a woman at this time, and unusual in showing the strength and determination of Judith and her maid. But we can also see it as a working out of her rage at being raped by one of her father's students at the age of 18." — <i>Ed Walker</i></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykdtyd-l-td/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>
entries.author: Matt Moore

entries.title: Lake View, Bronzeville neighborhood murders linked: police reports
entries.summary: <p>Two assailants who left a 22-year-old man lying dead in a Lake View street after shooting him and fleeing in his car apparently gunned down another man an hour later and 12 miles away in the Bronzeville neighborhood, according to police reports.</p><p>Police learned of the connection when the 22-year-old's vehicle was found at the scene of the second man’s murder, in the Oakland neighborhood on the South Side, according to the reports.</p><p>The names of both men have not been released yet, according to the Cook County medical examiner’s office. Autopsies are scheduled.</p><p>The first attack happened at 4 a.m. in the 700 block of West Waveland Avenue, according to police, who reviewed video that showed two attackers confronting the 22-year-old and a 38-year-old man who were seated in a parked vehicle in the according to a police report.</p><p>As a “physical confrontation” erupted among the four, the 22-year-old was shot and the two attackers jumped into his vehicle and sped away, leaving the 22-year-old Humboldt Park neighborhood man lying unresponsive in the street near the curb at <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/11/man-fatally-shot-during-lake-view-carjacking" target="_blank" >767 W. Waveland Ave.</a>, the report said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-fc0000" </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Mohammad Samra/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The 38-year-old man was not injured.</p><p>About one hour later in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/11/man-found-shot-to-death-in-oakland-neighborhood" target="_blank" >3700 block of South Lake Park Avenue</a>, Wentworth District police officers responded to a call of a person shot and found an unidentified man with an apparent gunshot wound to the head, also lying in the street a few feet away from a vehicle with its doors open, according to another police report.</p><p>The man, who police described as a “John Doe,” was pronounced dead at 5:03 a.m. by paramedics on the scene.</p><p>After going through all the evidence on the scene, detectives found the vehicle left on the scene with its doors open was the same car used in the murder and carjacking of the 22-year-old, the report said.</p><p>Area 3 and Area 1 detectives are investigating and nobody has been arrested.<br></p>

entries.title: Intuit, Driehaus museums to get nearly 100 prestigious art works
entries.summary: <p>In an unusual coincidence, two Chicago art museums announced substantial acquisitions on the same day this week — a total of 98 works dating from 1880 to 2020 by such creators as famed outsider artist William Hawkins and early 20th-century realist George Bellows.</p><p>The Intuit Art Museum, one of the most respected institutions devoted to self-taught or outsider art in the United States, added 61 works from two noted collectors in the field: Jan Petry, a longtime Intuit supporter who died in 2024, and Gordon W. Bailey of Los Angeles.</p><p>The Driehaus Museum, whose galleries occupy an opulent 1883 Gilded-Age residence at 50 E. Erie St., received 37 paintings and works on paper from the Chicago collections of M. Christine Schwartz and noted philanthropists Alexandra C. and John D. Nichols plus six long-term loans.</p><p>The acquisition news comes the same week as <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/art/2026/02/10/art-institute-chicago-norman-rockwell-cubs-painting" target="_blank" ><u>the Art Institute of Chicago’s </u></a>announcement that it acquired “The Dugout,” Norman Rockwell’s 1948 artwork depicting a dejected Chicago Cubs. The museum’s first-ever Rockwell went on display to visitors starting Wednesday.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-220000" name="image-220000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/786dcad/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/285b52f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6361b32/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Lucie Hartrath, The Creek, circa 1917, Gift of M. Christine Schwartz.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6361b32/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5eec1fc/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6361b32/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1456x817+0+330/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2Fa7%2F7e83f5cd43b8bf5a6f58f7d07a44%2Flucie-hartrath-the-creek-circa-1917-gift-of-m-christine-schwartz.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Among the new works acquired by the Driehaus Museum are paintings by late 19th- and early 20th-century women such as artist Lucie Hartrath.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Lucie Hartrath, The Creek, circa 1917, Gift of M. Christine Schwartz</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>More than ever, Debra Kerr, Intuit’s president and chief executive officer said, the Intuit Museum is trying to be “judicious and smart” when it adds new works to the collection.</p><p>“We are a small museum, and we can’t afford to have everything in the world,” Kerr said. “So, when we bring something into the collection these days, it’s stellar. We want the best possible work we can get.”</p><p>She believes its latest acquisitions fit that bill. Not only do the works significantly boost the overall size of the museum’s collection, they deepen its holdings of artists of color, particularly those by women, such as Alabama-born Brenda Davis. The Intuit’s collection now numbers about 1,500 objects.</p><p>Highlights among the 61 works include “Untitled (Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary)” (ca. 1970s), the museum’s first work by Sam Doyle (1906-85), an artist from the island of St. Helena off the coast of South Carolina. Another is a painting of Wrigley Field by William Hawkins (1895-1990), a renowned outsider artist from Columbus, Ohio.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-hangRight> <div class="Enhancement-item" class="Figure-content"><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Hope Atkinson (American, 1946-2012).Don’t Look Back This Way To A New Life, 2000. Acrylic on wood,24 1/4 x 15 3/4 x 1/8 in. Collection of Intuit Art Museum, gift of Gordon W. Bailey in honor of Marcia Weber, 2025<br></p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Petry’s gifts will go on view April 9, 2026 through March 21, 2027 in a show titled, “Life is an Art: The Collection of Jan Petry,” and Kerr expects examples from the Bailey donation to be shown in early 2027.</p><p>Until now, the Driehaus Museum, founded by financier and philanthropist Richard H. Driehaus, has mostly housed decorative arts from the late 19th and early 20th-century. Displays have revolved around such famed artists and workshops as Louis Comfort Tiffany and the Wiener Werkstätte.</p><p>Driehaus’ executive director, Lisa M. Key, said this latest round of acquisitions is a big step in fulfilling the museum’s desire to bolster its holdings of paintings, drawings and original prints. “Through working with these donors,” she said, “we’ve been able to exponentially grow the [fine art] works in our collection not only in a scale but also in a quality that we would never have been able to afford if we were to be purchasing them outright.”</p><p>The five paintings from the Schwartz collection include examples by late 19th- and early 20th-century women artists Pauline Dohn and Lucie Hartrath as well as William Clusmann’s “Untitled (Chicago Street Scene)” (ca. 1920s). The latter offers a historical look at the bustling intersection of Michigan Avenue and Adams Street.</p><p>The Nicholses (John died in 2023), who have been major backers of a range of Chicago cultural organizations including the Art Institute of Chicago and Music Institute of Chicago, donated 32 lithographs from 1897 to 1924 by Ashcan School artist George Bellows (1882-1925).</p><div on canvas, “Mountain Landscape”<i> </i>(1849), part of cash-strapped Valparaiso University’s<a class="Link" href="https://www.chicagotribune.com/2025/05/13/valparaiso-university-art-sale/" entries.author: Kyle MacMillan

entries.title: Trump EPA set to repeal scientific finding that serves as basis for US climate change policy
entries.summary: <p>WASHINGTON (AP) — The Trump administration on Thursday will revoke a scientific finding that long has been the central basis for U.S. action to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and fight <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/climate-and-environment" target="_blank" >climate change</a>, the White House announced.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/hub/us-environmental-protection-agency" target="_blank" >Environmental Protection Agency</a> will issue a final rule rescinding a 2009 government declaration known as the endangerment finding. That Obama-era policy determined that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases endanger public health and welfare.</p><p>President Donald Trump and EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin will “formalize the rescission of the 2009 Obama-era endangerment finding" at a White House ceremony, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Tuesday.</p><p>The action "will be the largest deregulatory action in American history, and it will save the American people $1.3 trillion in crushing regulations,” she said. The bulk of the savings will stem from reduced costs for new vehicles, with the EPA projecting average per vehicle savings of more than $2,400 for popular light-duty cars, SUVs and trucks, Leavitt said.</p><p>The endangerment finding is the <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/article/epa-endangerment-finding-zeldin-trump-climate-change-4b34246d5ca798154af08560fd94f7b9" target="_blank" >legal underpinning of nearly all climate regulations</a> under the Clean Air Act for motor vehicles, power plants and other pollution sources that are heating the planet. It is used to justify regulations, such as auto emissions standards, intended to protect against threats made increasingly severe by climate change — deadly floods, extreme heat waves, catastrophic wildfires and other natural disasters in the United States and around the world.</p><h2>Legal challenges certain to come</h2><p>Legal challenges are certain for any action that effectively would repeal those regulations, with environmental groups describing the shift as the single biggest attack in U.S. history on federal efforts to address climate change.</p><p>“The Trump administration is abandoning its core responsibility to keep us safe from extreme weather and accelerating climate change,'' said Abigail Dillen, president of the nonprofit law firm Earthjustice. “There is no way to reconcile EPA’s decision with the law, the science and the reality of disasters that are hitting us harder every year. Earthjustice and our partners will see the Trump administration in court.”</p><p>EPA press secretary Brigit Hirsch said the Obama-era rule was “one of the most damaging decisions in modern history” and said EPA “is actively working to deliver a historic action for the American people.”</p><p>Trump, who has called climate change a “hoax,” previously issued <a class="Link" href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/unleashing-american-energy/" target="_blank" >an executive order</a> that directed EPA to submit a report on “the legality and continuing applicability” of the endangerment finding. Conservatives and some congressional Republicans have long sought to undo what they consider overly restrictive and economically damaging rules to limit greenhouse gases that cause global warming.</p><p>Zeldin, a former Republican congressman who was tapped by Trump to lead EPA last year, has criticized his predecessors in Democratic administrations, saying they were <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/article/trump-climate-epa-endangerment-zeldin-5cba0871c880e23d044ef40a398c57b2" target="_blank" >“willing to bankrupt the country”</a> in an effort to combat climate change.</p><p>Democrats “created this endangerment finding and then they are able to put all these regulations on vehicles, on airplanes, on stationary sources, to basically regulate out of existence ... segments of our economy," Zeldin said in announcing the proposed rule last July. ”And it cost Americans a lot of money.”</p><p>Peter Zalzal, a lawyer and associate vice president of the Environmental Defense Fund, countered that the EPA will be encouraging more climate pollution, higher health insurance and fuel costs and thousands of avoidable premature deaths. The EPA is focusing solely on industry costs while ignoring the rule's climate and health benefits, he and other advocates said.</p><p>Zeldin’s push “is cynical and deeply damaging, given the mountain of scientific evidence supporting the finding, the devastating climate harms Americans are experiencing right now and EPA’s clear obligation to protect Americans’ health and welfare,” Zalzal said.</p><h2>Supreme Court has upheld endangerment finding</h2><p>The Supreme Court ruled in a 2007 case that planet-warming greenhouse gases, caused by burning of oil and other fossil fuels, are air pollutants under the Clean Air Act.</p><p>Since the high court’s decision, in a case known as <a class="Link" href="https://nam12.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fu7061146.ct.sendgrid.net%2Fls%2Fclick%3Fupn%3Du001.gqh-2BaxUzlo7XKIuSly0rC71V1zGV8xrgOOTNp90uc4hK9Q4LUXTGp-2FIwt04bUqVZwk1e2zS3tEArmKJLmuUkMSqEZ7inm-2BLkfYa-2BGLag8JuDMJ-2BkOUDhbLFPVn8MwbZ3ZAvhHROkUqEnaxSJ2GBko9996pZbkeU51PYG0DMfEA0FeKj74IN-2BweVF-2Fpy6bRlCS-2BMEpXVFzRIY8B6DB3MR619cmsyrshzXBiu-2B9BiqtBXMtsEi35YchKCuJALMO-2FRJu3AZJDq6FKIVsmqT9C4L6DSTyC0RGJhVD7-2Fpdad7rxJ0hzk87kg1hlbhuRXgzY-2Be7hQI1V6ExyRXx9y7t4gezNnLBqwmolhZhR3Vo2OpQ8YLFbQkyC-2B1WT02-2BPYFeKFHLRRgkIp2kNpiOjIqhgbYsAcRQCW5gbzGhgwuzyDf3HQA1f2Af8zWcgmcU1v03W6WEq4XWAysabeDYTffNHVlszTktd7Fb-2B3q4MJBIYvtIpujkHdocoZ1VCXxy8Zhb1nuWoh1M-2Br3LDqkN1eJAeQhkQqX2-2BDkVMxhX8lre5RugbZMia4yQBsFGQfhE6B0vEJci-2FEm5EyQQPhe8YyngDgREIUs3U8A1dzmQ1OBFjqBNi4-3D8nRS_SuYt8EWzCBCFJXOrlhZQt2TfY9BcyxUsWHxLNY-2BPnLxe9UooS0LV3GPam-2Fqk9k7r9QtMPZP5rgsaL-2F5Sq16ntOSmHN5oL4DBnx815JsXD-2B7Q4GYFW671UXZwvMicX6-2Bpj73yejLLv1MUjAVCWHl4wOvW4qYHh10aCkMavBkkS-2FXu5faHD-2Ffr9yP-2FaKAHc-2BTZwiCQE75m0iy9-2FhSpELN-2FlYPg-2BCi9DVYMAM8XBbFbp-2Bd-2FiiA4xuHbdq9s9TrGJGU84lPyxqrR51aY2PNk6z8hsjAw7tcfk2FFXj50VbXWxV7tQMHjWVExOfIX7nBop89CVT0Sm2X-2FC2bwM9cyoxd4hg-3D-3D&data=05%7C02%7Cmdaly%40ap.org%7C870ca7a9f2ac46c6743008de544775f4%7Ce442e1abfd6b4ba3abf3b020eb50df37%7C1%7C0%7C639040863129566468%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=d2CaiNr%2B91GKqUXKVWVuYYMj5cPY6%2F2yuBAlk7e05hc%3D&reserved=0" target="_blank" >Massachusetts v. EPA</a>, courts have uniformly rejected legal challenges to the endangerment finding, including a 2023 decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.</p><p>Following Zeldin's proposal to repeal the rule, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine <a class="Link" href="https://www.nationalacademies.org/news/national-academies-publish-new-report-reviewing-evidence-for-greenhouse-gas-emissions-and-u-s-climate-health-and-welfare" target="_blank" >reassessed the science underpinning</a> the 2009 finding and concluded it was "accurate, has stood the test of time, and is now reinforced by even stronger evidence.”</p><p>Much of the understanding of climate change that was uncertain or tentative in 2009 is now resolved, the NAS panel of scientists said in a September report. “The evidence for current and future harm to human health and welfare created by human-caused greenhouse gases is beyond scientific dispute,” the panel said.</p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: White Sox GM Chris Getz laughs off his mistakes about Luisangel Acuña being a switch hitter
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> are still getting to know <b>Luisangel Acuña</b> — right down to the very basics, apparently.</p><p>General manager<b> Chris Getz</b> ate a little crow Thursday after fans started hammering him on social media for repeatedly misidentifying the team’s main return from <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/01/21/white-sox-plan-to-be-very-active-in-upgrading-roster-after-trading-center-fielder-luis-robert-jr" target="_blank" ><u>the </u><b><u>Luis Robert Jr.</u></b><u> trade</u></a> as a switch hitter.</p><p>Getz labeled Acuña a switch hitter Monday while rattling off the right-handed utility player’s merits during a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/02/09/white-sox-100-losses-spring-training-rebuild" target="_blank" ><u>scrum with reporters at Camelback Ranch</u></a>.</p><p>"He can play all over the diamond," Getz said then. "He's a strong defender, base runner, switch hitter, can do a lot of different things to help you win."</p><p>Just not that last thing, as it turns out. Keen-eared Sox observers took note and then found three other instances of the GM making the same mistaken claim during the offseason, including at SoxFest.</p><p>“So I probably have been getting carried away describing his versatility,” Getz joked through a spokesman Thursday. “He can play every position on the field. Why does it have to stop there? I called Luisangel and told him that even though he’s just right-handed, we still love him.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Great job by many of you flagging this.<br><br>Here are FOUR different times this offseason where <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/WhiteSox?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#WhiteSox</a> GM Chris Getz has referred to Luisangel Acuña as a switch hitter.<br><br>Acuña is, in fact, NOT a switch hitter.<br><br>Not great. Four times isn’t a misspeak. <a href="https://t.co/yYYsHBH49w">pic.twitter.com/yYYsHBH49w</a></p>— Sam Phalen (@Sam_Phalen) <a href="https://twitter.com/Sam_Phalen/status/2021695837609263610?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 11, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Getz was back in Chicago after observing the first couple days of workouts after pitchers and catchers reported for spring training this week.</p><p>Acuña, the 23-year-old younger brother of 2023 National League MVP <b>Ronald Acuña Jr.</b>, hasn’t arrived yet to Glendale. Sox position players are scheduled to report Sunday.</p><p>Getz acquired him from the Mets last month along with right-hander Truman Pauley in exchange for Robert, the Sox GM’s last big trade chip as they look to turn a corner in their long slog of a rebuild. </p><p>Acuña, who batted .234/.293/.274 with in 95 games for the Mets last year mostly played at second base, is expected to open the season in center field for the Sox, “but we're not closing the door on the infield either,” Getz said this week.</p>
entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: 2 teens arrested after brawl during basketball game at Bronzeville high school prompts large police response
entries.summary: <p>Charges were pending for two 16-year-olds who were arrested when a brawl erupted after a basketball game at Dunbar Vocational Career Academy, prompting a large police response Wednesday night at the Bronzeville school. </p><p>Officers responded to the school, 3000 S. King Dr., for the fight where a 16-year-old boy and 16-year-old girl were both arrested as officers were trying to intervene, Chicago police said. </p><p>In a note to community members, Dunbar principal Richard McMillan said that the fight involved school community members and staffers who "helped de-escalate the situation and also notified the Chicago Police Department for additional support."</p><p>"Safety continues to be my top priority," McMillan said in the note. "While I cannot provide additional details for privacy reasons, I want to assure you that this situation is being handled in accordance with CPS policies."</p><p>"We will continue striving to help our students reach their full potential and exemplify our core values both in the classroom and in their extracurricular pursuits," McMillan added. </p><p>Charges were pending. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Top mayoral aide says Chicago's struggling taxi cab industry needs a fare hike
entries.summary: <p>Chicago needs to raise taxi cab fares for the first time since 2016 to save a once-thriving industry decimated by ridesharing and the pandemic, a top mayoral aide said Thursday.</p><p>“The tax industry is very dear to us. It has a lot of value in Chicago. It was here before” Uber and Lyft, Business Affairs and Consumer Protection Commissioner Ivan Capifali told the Sun-Times. “We want to make sure that they survive.”</p><p>Capifali essentially urged the City Council to approve the cab fare hike that Mayor Brandon Johnson introduced without fanfare in late September while public attention was focused on the battle over his 2026 budget.</p><p>The mayor’s plan would maintain the cost of entering a cab, known as the “flag pull” at $3.25 for the first one-ninth of a mile, but provide substantial relief for cab drivers in other ways. </p><p>They include a $2.50 rush hour fee for rides between 3:30 p.m. and 7 p.m., a $1 overnight fee for rides between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m and increased charges for both time and distance.</p><p>Instead of 25 cents for each additional one-ninth mile, passengers would pay 31 cents. Another 25 cents would be tacked onto the fare for every 36 seconds instead of 20 cents.</p><p>The ordinance has languished in committee for months, but Capifali said that needs to change to accommodate the "high cost of everything," including fuel, insurance and maintenance.</p><p>“They haven’t seen any fare increase in a while and that has led to other problems… We have received complaints from consumers that some taxi drivers are requesting a flat fee. That sometimes feels like they’re getting gouged. We have to make sure that doesn’t happen. Increasing the cab fare could be a solution to that," he said.</p><p>John Moberg, president of Checker, Yellow and American United Cab, said the pending increase is long overdue. Chicago cab drivers got some relief in 2022 when then-Mayor Lori Lightfoot imposed a temporary fuel surcharge. But it was only in place for about a year.</p><p>“Rideshare hurt us. But COVID was almost like the nail in the coffin. We have almost no business in the downtown or North Shore anymore,” Moberg said. “Insurance has gone up every year for the last several years. That’s our biggest expense. The industry needs a raise to stay competitive and stay available. It’s been a long time.”</p><p>Chicago’s once-thriving taxi cab industry has been shrinking ever since the unregulated advent of ride-hailing services like Lyft and Uber.</p><p>It took years before the city finally stepped in and regulated that industry. By that time, the value of taxi cab medallions already had plummeted. <br>A medallion that once sold for as much as $400,000 is now valued at $5,000.</p><p>The pool of available drivers also is shrinking — and aging. Anyone who got laid off or needs to supplement their income can “go to Uber and be driving tomorrow," while it takes two or three weeks of classes to be cleared to drive a cab, Moberg said.</p><p>“We don’t have new blood with younger people coming in. It’s the same people who have been there for years and they’re slowly retiring and dying off. That’s probably our biggest handicap," Moberg said. </p><p>In 2017, the taxi industry got what advocates then called a “death blow." That’s when the U.S. Supreme Court let stand a federal appeals court ruling that snuffed out an attempt by the cab companies to level what they called an uneven playing field that favored Uber, whose investors included then-Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s brother.</p><p>The appeals court ruling essentially said the business models of taxis and ride-hailing services are different and, therefore, they can continue to operate under different sets of rules in Chicago.</p><p>That decision validated a 2014 city ordinance letting Uber and Lyft operate without taxi medallions, city-regulated fares, driver fingerprinting or other regulations cab companies and their drivers must follow. Uber and Lyft had long maintained that a background check based on FBI fingerprinting would discriminate against minorities.</p><p>In 2016, a divided City Council agreed to license ride-hailing drivers but opted not to require fingerprinting after Uber and Lyft threatened to abandon the Chicago market.</p><p>On Thursday, Moberg renewed his appeal for "the same regulations for both" the taxicab and rideshare industries.</p><p>“Their cars don’t have to be inspected. Ours do. They can go to any gas station and get a certificate. Our cars have to go to inspection lanes two or three times a year,” Moberg said. “Is the public safer in a rideshare car? Same thing with drivers."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4c0000" name="html-embed-module-4c0000"></a><iframe allow="monetization" frameborder="0" height="200" scrolling="no" src="https://play.prx.org/e?ge=prx_12963_8c00227b-d907-4999-8cf3-431b53c1af58&uf=https%3A%2F%2Fpublicfeeds.net%2Ff%2F12963%2Ffeed-rss.xml" style="min-width: 300px;" width="100%"> </iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Fran Spielman

entries.title: Mr. Friday Night? The Bulls' Matas Buzelis looking to shed that title
entries.summary: <p>BOSTON — Friday night’s game isn’t where Matas Buzelis wants to be.</p><p>The second-year <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" >Bulls</a> forward will take it, he’ll speak about it with gratitude and look to put on a show, but in his world the NBA’s Rising Stars Game is a rung on the ladder. A ladder he is not even close to finishing climbing.</p><p>“Everything is exciting for me still,” Buzelis said of his trip to Los Angeles for All-Star Weekend. “Anything you get to participate in is an honor and exciting, but I’m not going to lie, yeah, I want to be in that Sunday game for sure.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/11/bears-caleb-williams-to-participate-in-celebrity-3-point-contest" >Bears’ Caleb Williams to participate in celebrity 3-point contest during NBA All-Star Weekend</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>That’s because Sunday is the varsity game. That’s when the best of the best cap off the weekend with the NBA All-Star Game. The showcase event. That’s always been the end game for Buzelis since the Bulls selected him in the 2024 draft — winning and to be the best.</p><p>Easy to lay out as goals, but as Buzelis is finding out, it’s a journey that comes with bruises and disappointment. He’s been reminded of that in the last week alone.</p><p>Gone from the locker room are a majority of the veteran players that helped raise him as a rookie last season and into the summer. Coby White, Nikola Vucevic, Ayo Dosunmu and Kevin Huerter all traded by last Thursday’s deadline.</p><p>Maybe that’s why the Buzelis hype train has again slowed down, awaiting the next fix.</p><p>It’s not like he’s been bad in the four games since the roster purge. There just haven’t been many takeover moments. Rookies like Cooper Flagg and Kon Knueppel have already had takeover moments this season. It’s Year 2 for Buzelis and while there are highlights and glimpses, those are more teases than trends. He is more than aware of that.</p><p>“I’m fully capable of becoming a great player and this is just the process it is going to be for me,” Buzelis said. “But I know for a fact that every year I’m going to get better as a player. I know that will happen. I’m going to work extremely hard, push myself until exhaustion to become that player. I’m more worried about this team and as a collective group what can we achieve. I’m all up for the challenge of becoming whatever people say or believe — All-Star, yada, yada.”</p><p>So when?</p><p>Easy to ask but difficult to answer.</p><p>“What I’m concerned about is I totally understand on the stat sheet that assists are going to be a reflection of made baskets, and consistently before (these trades) happened we were a team that was 28-30-some assists per game, and we come out of the first half (against Boston on Wednesday) with eight assists,” coach Billy Donovan said when asked about concerns for Buzelis inconsistent play lately. “We need to learn how to play the right way, everybody. Whether it be Matas or Patrick (Williams), they’ve been here and they know how we have to play. Nobody is going to look good when you’re not helping each other.”</p><p>Another gut-punch that Buzelis is trying to deal with? Winning is his top priority and it is sinking in that his franchise is in the midst of a soft tank.</p><p>“It is hard but what can you do? You’re not going home and crying about it,” Buzelis said of the team and where it is in the standings. “You’ve just got to wake up and get back to work. I do understand that it’s going to be difficult to get into a groove as a team, but we’re all up for that challenge. Sooner or later, the sun will shine.”</p><p>Likely in LA, where Buzelis did make one promise about the Rising Stars Game. Or maybe it was a warning.</p><p>“This game is the league’s future and there is a lot of hype around some of these guys,” Buzelis added. “I’m looking forward to going out there and competing against them, sharing a moment, building relationships with, but if it goes down to a one-on-one situation in these games against any guy, we’re going at each other and that’s just how it is.”</p><p>Friday night will have to do for now.</p><p></p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true"
