entries.author: Michael O'Brien

entries.title: Hombre de Chicago absuelto del complot de asesinato de Bovino sigue detenido tras que juez le negó la fianza
entries.summary: <p>Un juez de inmigración negó la fianza a un hombre de Chicago, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/01/22/federal-jury-rejects-bovino-murder-plot-after-called-upon-stand-up-overreaching-government" target="_blank" >absuelto el mes pasado</a> de orquestar un complot de asesinato por encargo contra el comandante de la Patrulla Fronteriza, Gregory Bovino, y lo calificó de “potencial” peligro para la comunidad a pesar del veredicto.</p><p>En una audiencia de fianza el miércoles, el juez Matthew Beese dijo que los abogados del Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS) presentaron evidencia “sustancial” del juicio criminal para respaldar su afirmación de que él representaba un peligro.</p><p>Los fiscales en ese juicio no lograron probar su caso más allá de una duda razonable, según lo determinó un jurado. Pero Beese enfatizó que su decisión se basaba en los estándares de la corte de inmigración, los cuales difieren de aquellos en la corte criminal.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-030000" name="module-030000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Los abogados del DHS pasaron una parte significativa de la audiencia presentando evidencia que había sido rechazada por el jurado durante el juicio criminal o prohibida por el juez que lo supervisó.</p><p>Los abogados citaron el miércoles un informe de Investigaciones de DHS que incluía registros telefónicos que alegaban que Espinoza Martínez, de 37 años de edad, estaba afiliado a los Latin Kings y tenía acceso a armas de fuego.</p><p>También señalaron un mensaje de Snapchat que Espinoza Martínez envió a principios de octubre, que seguía a una foto de Bovino. El mensaje decía: “2k en info cuando lo agarren,” “10k si lo derribas,” y “LK … sobre él”.</p><p>Bovino fue la cara del Operativo Midway Blitz, la agresiva campaña de deportación de la administración de Trump en el área de Chicago el año pasado.</p><p>Los fiscales en el caso penal no se propusieron probar la afiliación de Espinoza Martínez con los Latin Kings. Sin esa afirmación, la jueza del distrito Joan Lefkow <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/01/09/fiscales-ya-no-intentaran-comprobar-que-hombre-acusado-de-poner-recompensa-por-greg-bovino-era-pandillero" target="_blank" >prohibió la evidencia relacionada con pandillas</a> en su juicio.</p><p>Espinoza Martínez ha estado en custodia federal durante más de cuatro meses desde su arresto por cargos de asesinato por encargo a principios de octubre, según muestran los registros.</p><p>El jurado absolvió a Espinoza Martínez el 22 de enero después de un breve juicio en la Corte de Justicia Federal Dirksen. Fue <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/01/26/hombre-absuelto-del-complot-de-asesinato-de-gregory-bovino-es-detenido-por-ice" target="_blank" >rápidamente llevado a la custodia</a> del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE).</p><p>Los funcionarios del DHS han acusado a Espinoza Martínez de estar en el país ilegalmente.</p><p>Sussethe Rentería, abogada de inmigración que representa a Espinoza Martínez, dijo que ingresó al país a los 5 años y que Chicago era “el único hogar que conoce”.</p><p>Rentería rechazó las afirmaciones de que Espinoza Martínez representara un peligro para la comunidad o un riesgo de fuga, diciendo que Seguridad Nacional estaba “intentos de revivir el caso criminal” a pesar de su absolución.</p><p>Destacó que Espinoza Martínez no tenía antecedentes penales aparte de infracciones menores de tránsito y negó que tuviera alguna implicación con una pandilla.</p><p>“Aunque respetamos la decisión de la corte, estamos decepcionados con el resultado”, dijo Rentería después de la audiencia. “Él cuenta con el apoyo inquebrantable de su comunidad y su familia, y tiene tres hijos y una esposa desesperada por que regrese a casa. Estamos seguros de que se hará justicia”.</p><p>Rentería comentó que estaba considerando apelar la decisión de la corte.</p><p>Durante la audiencia, Rentería también presentó una declaración del concejal Michael Rodriguez (22°) que afirmaba que Espinoza Martínez, que vive en el vecindario de La Villita, “no tenía conexión con actividades de pandillas”. Enfatizó que simplemente vivir en un vecindario con presencia de pandillas no convierte a alguien en miembro de una pandilla.</p><p>La semana pasada, un juez federal en Indiana <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/04/juez-federal-ordena-no-deportar-a-hombre-de-chicago-exonerado-del-complot-de-asesinato-de-bovino" target="_blank" >bloqueó temporalmente</a> a la administración de Trump de deportar a Espinoza Martínez, quien estaba detenido en el Centro de Justicia del Condado de Clay en Brazil, Indiana. Su abogado, Michael Adler, presentó una petición el 2 de febrero en el Distrito Sur de Indiana para impugnar su detención.</p><p>El juez ordenó a la administración de Trump que no moviera a Espinoza Martínez “fuera de la jurisdicción de los Estados Unidos”, o fuera del 7° Circuito —que incluye Illinois, Indiana y Wisconsin— mientras se avanza en el litigio.</p><p>Se programó una audiencia de expulsión para el 25 de febrero. Rentería dijo que presentará una solicitud para cancelar la expulsión.</p><p><i>Contribuyó: Jon Seidel </i></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por</i> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Voters cast ballots at Loop Supersite as early voting kicks off
entries.summary: <p>Voters looking to avoid long lines cast their ballots Thursday morning in the Loop as early voting opened for the Illinois primary election.</p><p>Kamilah Banks-Word didn’t want to wait to vote, so she stopped by the new voting supersite at 137 S. State St. on her way to work.</p><p>“Voting makes a difference in terms of how our society runs,” said Banks-Word, 47. “I think a lot of us are not aware of how important the primary and midterm elections are. Most people just vote for the presidency, and we see how that turned out.”</p><p>Banks-Word, of the South Loop, said she was voting to protect people’s rights across the country and wanted everyone to feel safe wherever they are.</p><p>“Everything's at stake at this point,” she said. “We've seen how everything has been going downhill, how people are being harassed by different political groups and law enforcement agents.”</p><p>Banks-Word wasn’t the only one encouraged to vote because of the Trump administration’s aggressive immigration enforcement campaign, which has sent hundreds of federal agents into cities across the country — including Chicago.</p><p>In early December, the Department of Homeland Security said at least 4,400 people had been detained during Operation Midway Blitz, the Chicago area campaign.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-2e0000" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Erick El, of Uptown, hadn’t voted in years but felt it was time to do something to overturn elected officials who he said were “tearing America apart.”</p><p>“We need to get Trump out of office,” said El, 54. “He's ripping families apart. People are losing their lives.”</p><p>The federal funding cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, and Medicaid also pushed El to cast his vote.</p><p>“People need their health insurance, and people need to eat,” El said.</p><p>Among the people in Chicago <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/06/walmart-amazon-cps-top-employers-illinois-workers-still-need-snap-benefits-trump-work-requirements-lose-benefits" target="_blank" >living in SNAP households</a> who are 22 or older, 47% are employed but still need government support to help buy groceries, according to 2024 U.S. Census data analyzed by WBEZ.</p><p>Early voting for the March 17 election started Thursday at the supersite and at the Chicago Board of Elections office at 69 W. Washington St. Early voting in all Chicago wards begins March 2.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-240000" name="image-240000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/866cfde/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6448x3619+0+340/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0e%2F24%2F2d2a142048dc80433274e35554ab%2Fearlyvoting-260213-6.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Carley Smelser, an election judge, assists Erick El in casting his ballot Thursday for the primary election at the early voting supersite in the Loop.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Don’t wait until the last second,” Chicago Board of Elections Chair Marisel Hernandez said at a morning media briefing at the supersite.</p><p>Hernandez also said the board would ensure that all voters feel safe casting their ballots after a former White House aide said federal agents should be at polling sites.</p><p>“Every voter has the right to register to vote and then vote free of intimidation, threats and coercion,” Hernandez said. “We have federal and state laws that prohibit any type of intimidation of voters during elections, and in fact, these laws specifically prohibit the presence of federal officers at any polling place.”</p><p>White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said last week that she <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/live/donald-trump-news-updates-2-5-2026" target="_blank" >“can’t guarantee”</a> a federal agent wouldn’t be near a polling location.</p><p>“I mean, that’s, frankly, a very silly hypothetical question,” said Leavitt. “But what I can tell you is, I haven’t heard the president discuss any formal plans to put ICE outside of polling locations. It’s a disingenuous question.”</p><p>Hernandez said all election judges know to call the board and 911 if they see any unusual activity near voting sites.</p><p>Officials also reminded voters casting ballots by mail to return them quickly after the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/04/usps-postmark-change-could-threaten-mail-in-voters-cook-county-officials-warn" target="_blank" >U.S. Postal Service announced</a> that it could not guarantee ballots would be postmarked before Election Day.</p><p>Under the new policy, mail will be postmarked, then date-stamped, on the day it is processed at the post office, rather than the day it is dropped in a mailbox.</p><p>Because mail is often processed days after it is dropped off, if ballots are postmarked after Election Day it could jeopardize whether votes are counted. Mail-in ballots must be postmarked by Election Day and received within 14 days to be counted.</p><p>“Don't risk a late postmark on your ballot,” said Hernandez. “Your vote needs to be counted.”</p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: DePaul and Loyola accused of pushing low-income families toward hefty loans while favoring wealthier students
entries.summary: <p>Two Chicago universities are among a few dozen colleges across the country that appear to favor wealthier families when offering financial aid packages, a new report finds.</p><p>Loyola University Chicago and DePaul University were named in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.newamerica.org/education-policy/reports/parent-plus-subprime-loans-universities-debt/" target="_blank" ><u>report released Thursday by the progressive think tank New America</u></a>, alleging they are among 41 colleges nationwide that push a large share of lower-income families to take out hefty loans to cover college costs while offering attractive scholarships to wealthier families with high-achieving students.</p><p>The schools in the report have a high percentage of lower-income families taking out loans they often can’t afford to pay back, according to the report’s author Steven Burd, a senior writer and editor with the education policy program at New America. The amount parents take out in loans is sometimes more than their annual earnings, the report found.</p><p>“The fear is really that they're just putting these families into real financial trouble, real financial jeopardy,” Burd said.</p><p>The report focuses on federal Parent PLUS loans, which parents can use to pay for tuition costs that can’t be covered out of pocket or through scholarships.</p><p>While most federal student loans have limits, families can take out Parent PLUS loans up to the total cost of attendance. But Parent PLUS loans, which have a high fixed interest rate and origination fees, weren’t designed for low-income families, Burd said. They were meant to help middle- and upper-income families send their children to more prestigious and expensive schools, he added.</p><p>“They were never intended as a way for schools to be able to help low-income students,” Burd said.</p><p>DePaul officials say the university provides scholarships and grants and offers information about various loans and provides but ultimately families decide what to borrow. A Loyola University spokesperson said he wanted to review the study before commenting further.</p><p>With Parent PLUS loans, the schools are not held accountable if the borrowers go into default, and the Trump administration is expected to soon start garnishing wages from people who have defaulted on student loans after a pause on payments that started during the COVID-19 pandemic.</p><p>Schools can offer students merit-based scholarships based on grades and academic success, even if they don’t qualify for need-based aid. And those scholarships can end up taking up a large share of a school’s financial aid funds, leaving low-income students in need of loans — and that’s where the Parent PLUS loans come in, Burd says.</p><p>The problem compounds, Burd says, when schools offer better financial aid packages to students whose families make more, a strategy he says is often aimed at attracting high-achieving and wealthy students who could give generous donations in the future. That incentivizes colleges to recruit students with an eye for “raising revenue for your institution and rising up the rankings,” Burd said.</p><p>Some schools have used this practice to improve their spot in national rankings and transform themselves from a humble commuter school to a nationally competitive university, the report says.</p><p>To find schools that appeared to be steering lower-income families toward Parent PLUS loans, Burd looked for colleges where a large share of students who received federal Pell Grants, which are meant for low-income students, had parents taking out Parent PLUS loans.</p><p>At DePaul University, 53% of students whose parents took out Parent PLUS loans were Pell Grant recipients and their parents borrowed on average $33,000 in PLUS loans, according to the report.</p><p>At Loyola, 48% of students whose parents have Parent PLUS loans had Pell grants. The average Parent PLUS debt taken on by those Loyola parents was around $46,000.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-3f0000" name="image-3f0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/32606e3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/05f5575/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3c844ab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d797611/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3c844ab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>At Loyola University Chicago, 48% of students whose parents have Parent PLUS loans received Pell grants for lower-income students. Their average debt load is around $46,000.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“These are families making $30,000 or less, and then they're taking on $30,000 in debt to put their kids through school,” Burd said. “These schools are charging so much, they're leaving such a large financial aid gap that the families have no other choice but to take out these PLUS loans.”</p><p>A DePaul University spokesperson said the school works to ease the financial burden on students, but didn’t directly address questions about low-income families taking out Parent PLUS loans or how the school decides what aid to offer to wealthier students. The spokesperson said DePaul provides students over $350 million a year in academic scholarships and need-based grants using institutional funds and philanthropic gifts.</p><p>“DePaul offers information to students and families regarding various loan options, and ultimately families make the decision to proceed with loans as they see fit,” the spokesperson wrote in a statement.</p><p>The 41 private and public colleges and universities cited in the report collectively spent $2.4 billion of their financial aid dollars on students who didn’t need the help in 2023, the most recent data available. Nearly $2 out of every $5 spent on financial aid went to students who the federal government considers able to afford college without additional aid, the report found.</p><p></p><p>Burd started with a list of more than 300 selective colleges and universities with a certain size endowment, excluding historically Black colleges and universities because he said they have been historically underfunded and have far less financial aid to give. Art schools were also excluded because they are among the most expensive schools, partly because of costly supplies and tools.</p><p>Burd then looked for schools at which families of Pell Grant recipients made up at least one-third of PLUS loan borrowers and the median amount of loans was at least $15,000. At the 41 schools cited in the report, 45% of the borrowers were the parents of Pell recipients, and they borrowed a median amount of $29,102.</p><p>Some lawmakers have noted this trend and have capped Parent PLUS loans at $65,000 per child, but Burd says that’s still too much for many families to borrow. He said ideally, legislation will be implemented to stop schools from steering families toward taking out loans they can’t afford to repay.</p><p>“The only other worry, though, is that private lenders are going to come in and start offering even more predatory products,” he said. “So that's something we need to look out for as well.”<br></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Portillo’s names Brett Patterson as CEO
entries.summary: <p>Portillo’s, the restaurant chain known for Chicago-style hot dogs and Italian beef sandwiches, named Brett Patterson as CEO and president, effective Feb. 23, on Wednesday.</p><p>Patterson’s appointment comes after Portillo’s announced in September that former CEO Michael Osanloo <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/work/2025/09/23/portillos-ceo-michael-osanloo-resigns-immediately" >would step down amid flagging business</a> at the Oak Brook-based fast casual restaurant chain.</p><p>Patterson was most recently CEO of Miller’s Ale House, a sports-themed casual dining chain with more than 100 locations in 10 states, according to its website. He was previously president of Outback Steakhouse and has served as president of Ruby Tuesday and an executive at Darden Restaurants, according to a securities filing.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Portillo’s appointed Brett Patterson as president and CEO.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesty of Portillo’s</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>As CEO, Patterson will lead Portillo’s overall strategy, “with a focus on market positioning, new restaurant growth and operational excellence,” a news release said. He will also join the company’s board of directors.</p><p>“This is a tremendous brand with a powerful culture, an incredibly passionate fan base, a long runway for growth and a team that truly cares about delivering great experiences,” Patterson said in a news release.</p><p>Patterson “brings the strategic mindset, operations expertise and leadership style needed to grow this brand, while preserving what makes Portillo’s so special and unique,” Michael Miles Jr., chairman of Portillo’s board, said in a news release. </p><p>In September, Portillo’s announced a “strategic reset” and lowered its financial targets for the year to “reflect an anticipated decline of current trends for the remainder of 2025 given pricing and promotional dynamics within the industry.”</p><p>Portillo’s most recent earnings report from third quarter 2025 reflected sluggish sales. Operating income was $5.4 million, down 66% from $16 million, compared to the same quarter last year. Net income was $0.8 million, a 91.1% decline from $8.8 million.</p><p>Osanloo helped take <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/business/2021/10/12/22723093/portillos-ipo-initial-public-stock-offering-beef-sandwiches-hot-dogs" >Portillo’s public in 2021</a> and raised $405 million in its IPO. But the company has since scaled back its ambitious plans for a national expansion.</p><p>Last year, it lowered targets for new restaurant openings from 12 to eight for the fiscal year 2026.</p><p>Meanwhile, in 2024, hedge fund Engaged Capital took a 9.9% stake in Portillo’s to push for changes. The California-based activist fund said it aimed to “unlock the intrinsic value” of the company. That could include “optimizing restaurant performance, improving restaurant-level cash on cash returns, enhancing corporate governance (including through potential changes to the composition of the Board) and/or exploring a sale,” Engaged said in a securities filing.</p><p>In 2023, workers at a Portillo’s food production center in Addison voted to unionize and become members of the Iron Workers Union. The employees prepare and deliver food to the chain’s Chicago-area restaurants. They agitated for higher wages and safer conditions in 2021, a campaign that included a brief strike.</p><p>Portillo’s was founded in 1963 by Dick Portillo in Villa Park and has grown from a small hot dog trailer to more than 90 restaurants across 10 states.</p>
entries.author: Amy Yee

entries.title: ¿Cuántos residentes de Chicago son de los países que Bad Bunny mencionó en su show del Super Bowl?
entries.summary: <p>Ha habido mucho que analizar en el espectáculo de medio tiempo del Super Bowl del músico Bad Bunny, que rindió un homenaje afectuoso a su <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/music/2026/02/03/bad-bunnys-hottest-local-super-bowl-pregame-is-at-the-chicago-public-library" target="_blank" >Puerto Rico natal</a> con simbólicos detalles.</p><p>Sin embargo, una parte cerca del final de su actuación de 13 minutos, realizada predominantemente en español, destacó por ser una de las pocas veces que habló en inglés.</p><p>Bad Bunny proclamó “God Bless América” (“Dios bendiga América”) en inglés, antes de nombrar docenas de países y territorios del hemisferio occidental, comenzando desde Chile en Sudamérica hasta Canadá en Norteamérica y finalizando con Puerto Rico. Luego, lanzó un balón de fútbol americano pintado con las palabras en inglés “Together, we are America” (“Juntos somos América”)”.</p><p>Académicos locales dicen que su mensaje era claro: el músico puertorriqueño estaba redefiniendo lo que significa ser “americano” más allá de solo los 50 estados de los Estados Unidos.</p><p>“La mayoría de los estadounidenses, cuando hablamos de Estados Unidos, lo llamamos América como si Estados Unidos fuera la única nación que es América, pero para las personas en Latinoamérica y el Caribe, América se refiere a todo el hemisferio”, dijo Lilia Fernández, profesora de historia en la Universidad de Illinois en Chicago (UIC).</p><p>Fernández afirma que el mensaje unificador de Bad Bunny probablemente <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/09/la-alegria-llena-humboldt-park-durante-la-fiesta-de-medio-tiempo-del-benito-bowl" target="_blank" >resonó con muchos en Chicago</a> que son de los países o territorios que nombró o son descendientes de familiares que nacieron allí.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-a30000" name="html-embed-module-a30000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27595327"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27595327/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="chart visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>Un análisis de WBEZ de datos del Censo de la encuesta comunitaria estadounidense más reciente estima que aproximadamente 1 de cada 8 habitantes de Chicago nació fuera de los 50 estados de Estados Unidos pero en uno de los países o territorios que conforman el hemisferio occidental, que abarca desde Sudamérica, Centroamérica y Norteamérica.</p><p>México es, con mucho, el lugar de origen más común para los habitantes de Chicago nacidos fuera de los 50 estados de Estados Unidos, seguido por Puerto Rico, Ecuador, Guatemala y Venezuela, en ese orden.</p><p>Por supuesto, el número de habitantes de Chicago que se identifican como hijos o nietos de personas nacidas en esos lugares probablemente sea mucho mayor. El mensaje final de Bad Bunny se basa en una crítica centenaria a los Estados Unidos como la única “América”, dijo Mérida M. Rúa, profesora de estudios latinos y latinas en la Universidad Northwestern.</p><p>Rúa dice que artistas como el músico y político latino Rubén Blades, en su álbum de 1984 “Buscando América”, han señalado explícitamente la idea de América como un continente. Cientos de años antes que Blades, la visión panamericana de Simón Bolívar, quien lideró la lucha contra el dominio colonial español en Sudamérica, fue sostenida por eruditos como el poeta cubano José Martí en su ensayo de 1891 “Nuestra América”.</p><p>Aunque Bad Bunny es el más reciente de una larga línea de personas que han reformulado el significado de “América”, es el primero en hacerlo en un escenario tan grande como el espectáculo de medio tiempo del Super Bowl de la NFL.</p><p>También es una declaración poderosa para hacer en el actual entorno político, dijo Fernández. Justo el mes pasado, las fuerzas militares de Estados Unidos capturaron al presidente venezolano Nicolás Maduro. Mientras tanto, la administración de Trump continúa sus campañas de cumplimiento de la ley de inmigración en todo el país. El domingo, el presidente Donald Trump calificó el espectáculo de medio tiempo del Super Bowl como “absolutamente terrible” y “una ofensa a la Grandeza de Estados Unidos” en una publicación en la red social Truth Social. </p><p>“Parecía ser un mensaje de inclusión y una visión alternativa a las políticas que estamos viendo ahora mismo en los Estados Unidos, particularmente las que provienen de la Casa Blanca y los partidarios del presidente y sus políticas de cumplimiento”, aseguró Fernández.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Amy Qin | WBEZ

entries.title: Chicago-area resident sues Trump officials over Facebook shutting down popular ICE sighting page
entries.summary: <p>The founder of one of the largest Facebook pages to track and report federal immigration activity activity in the Chicago area during the Trump administration's Operation Midway Blitz is fighting back after Facebook disabled the page in October.</p><p>In a <a class="Link" href="https://www.thefire.org/sites/default/files/2026/02/Verified%20Complaint%20-%20Rosado%20v.%20Bondi.pdf " target="_blank" >lawsuit filed Wednesday</a>, Cicero small business owner Kassandra "Kae" Rosado alleged U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi and U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem coerced Facebook into removing the popular "ICE Sighting-Chicagoland" page, violating Rosado's First Amendment rights. </p><p>"Defendants retaliated against Rosado's Facebook group for the simple reason that the government disfavors the speech being shared. But the government has no legitimate interest in 'stopping private actors from speaking as they wish' to 'tilt public debate in a preferred direction,'" the lawsuit reads.</p><p>Rosado started the page in January 2025 to keep individuals and small businesses informed about where U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement was operating in Chicago, according to the lawsuit. The page was initially made up of fellow business owners and Rosado's friends and family. Group membership increased in September as ICE enforcement surged in the city and surrounding suburbs. </p><p>The page had almost 100,000 members by October, with thousands of posts and comments per day from members sharing information about violent encounters and arrests across the city, according to the lawsuit.</p><p>But on Oct. 12, right-wing activist and Trump ally Laura Loomer <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/LauraLoomer/status/1977345952718438707" target="_blank" >tagged Noem and Bondi in a post</a> claiming that the Facebook page and others like it "are getting people killed." The next day, Loomer <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/LauraLoomer/status/1977812771799461893?s=20" target="_blank" >said in a post</a> that a Department of Justice source told her that they had contacted executives at Meta, Facebook's parent company, "to tell them they need to remove these ICE tracking pages from the platform." </p><p>Noem and Bondi announced the removal of the Facebook page on their social media accounts on Oct. 14. "Anti-ICE radicals are using social media apps to dox, threaten, and terrorize the brave men and women of ICE and their families," Noem <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/Sec_Noem/status/1978182132414448008?s=20 " target="_blank" >said in the post. </a></p><p>According to the suit, Rosado was notified by Facebook that the page was disabled because it "went against the Community Standards multiple times." </p><p>While the page was active, the suit said Facebook moderators had removed five posts in the group that were not created or approved by Rosado or her moderators. Additionally, the suit said Facebook had previously advised Rosado that "it had only identified this handful of 'participant violations' of its rules, which 'don't hurt your group.'"</p><p>"By censoring our group, the government continues to erode our trust," Rosado said in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.thefire.org/news/fire-sues-bondi-noem-censoring-facebook-group-and-app-reporting-ice-activity" target="_blank" >statement</a>. "They silenced not only my voice, but the voices of nearly 100,000 other community members."</p><p>Rosado filed the suit with Mark Hodges, an Indiana resident who created the app Eyes Up, which allowed users to record, securely store and view videos of ICE officers committing potential civil rights violations. According to the suit, Apple removed the app from the App Store in October, allegedly after pressure from the federal government and violating Hodges' First Amendment-protected right to record law enforcement in public.</p><p>The Department of Justice, Apple and Meta did not respond immediately to requests for comment.</p><p>In a statement, the Department of Homeland Security's Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said, "ICE tracking apps put the lives of the men and women of law enforcement in danger as they go after terrorists, vicious gangs and violent criminal rings."</p><p>"But, of course, FIRE spins this correct decision for Apple to remove these apps as them caving to pressure instead of helping prevent further harm to federal officers," she added.</p><p>The lawsuit asks the court to declare that Bondi and Noem's coercion of Facebook and Apple suppressed disfavored speech, which violates the First Amendment.</p><p>"Plaintiffs bring this case to preserve our country's fundamental character as a free nation, asking this Court to protect the basic First Amendment right to share information about our government and its activities," the suit said.</p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: Review: Goodman production of ‘Holiday’ is a respectful adaptation of 1928 original that also feels fresh
entries.summary: <p>The phrase “adaptation” can have so many meanings when it comes to plays that the description communicates little.</p><p>Sure, when a stage adaptation comes from a novel, we know it’s a transposition of form at a minimum, requiring a creative leap but with highly varying degrees of faithfulness. When the source play was written in a foreign language, “adapted by” usually means the translator has gone beyond just line-by-line conversion into English, but sometimes very little, sometimes a whole lot.</p><p>With the amiable, elevated Goodman production of “Holiday,” though, we get something that seems extremely rare: a well-known title — produced four times previously by the Goodman and remembered fondly by screwball comedy buffs for the Cary Grant-Katharine Hepburn film version — that is truly, aggressively and yet still respectfully “adapted” from the Philip Barry 1928 original by Richard Greenberg. (Thank the expiration of the play’s copyright, which spurred the Barry estate to commission something sufficiently original to be a newly protected, authorized version.)</p><div class="RatingCard Enhancement" data-module data-rating="3.5" data-align-center> <div class="RatingCard-title"> Holiday </div> <div class="RatingCard-content"> <span class="RatingCard-star"> <span class="RatingCard-star-full"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star-half"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star"> <span class="RatingCard-star-full"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star-half"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star"> <span class="RatingCard-star-full"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star-half"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star"> <span class="RatingCard-star-full"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> <span class="RatingCard-star-half"> <svg class=""> <use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use> </svg> </span> </span> </div> </div><p></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ca0000" name="module-ca0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b>When:</b> Through March 1<br><b>Where:</b> Goodman Theater, 170 N. Dearborn St.<br><b>Tickets:</b> $34-$104<br><b>Info:</b> <a class="Link" href="https://www.goodmantheatre.org/show/holiday/" target="_blank" >goodmantheatre.org</a><br><b>Run time:</b> 2 hours and 20 minutes with one intermission<br></div> </div><p>You might say Greenberg, the uber-talented author of “Take Me Out,” “Three Days of Rain” and many more witty, sophisticated plays, who so sadly passed away last year at the age of 67, kept the structure but took it down to the studs.</p><p>This is a faithful re-creation of Barry’s story. Long-orphaned, up-from-nothing lawyer Johnny Case (Luigi Sottile) discovers that his new fiancée Julia Seton (Molly Griggs) comes from “those Setons,” an extremely wealthy old-money family living in a New York City mansion. A battle of values ensues: Johnny declares his intention to take a “holiday” from work after earning his first significant pile of cash, which an upcoming deal will accomplish. He wants to pursue happiness, even if he doesn’t yet know the details. Yes, he wants money, but not “too much.”</p><p>Julia is baffled, as is her high-expectation father Edward (Jordan Lage). But Julia’s siblings, freer-spirited older sister Linda (Bryce Gangel) and oft-intoxicated younger brother Ned (Wesley Taylor), take Johnny’s side.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-460000" name="image-460000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" alt="1_Holiday Production Photos: (L-R) Molly Griggs, Wesley Taylor, Bryce Gangel, Luigi Sottile, Jordan Lage." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2dffd5e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6691x3755+652+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdc%2F80%2F4a3e4879457d9042ae5e511e4fa7%2F1-holiday-production-photos.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/07c56d0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6691x3755+652+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdc%2F80%2F4a3e4879457d9042ae5e511e4fa7%2F1-holiday-production-photos.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2dffd5e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6691x3755+652+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fdc%2F80%2F4a3e4879457d9042ae5e511e4fa7%2F1-holiday-production-photos.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Molly Griggs (from left), Wesley Taylor, Bryce Gangel, Luigi Sottile and Jordan Lage star in The Goodman’s “Holiday.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Todd Rosenberg</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>That synopsis applies to both the Barry and Greenberg versions. But this is far more than a straightforward updating to contemporary times, from just pre-Depression to just pre-pandemic.</p><p>The dialogue is nearly all Greenberg’s. It has his rhythm, wit, edge, voice. If this does go to Broadway — there are aspirations — watch out for an intriguing debate about whether this qualifies as a revival or a new play.</p><p>As directed by the Goodman’s former longtime leader Robert Falls, “Holiday” feels fresh, bereft of mothballs. Walt Spangler’s beautiful set design brings both the fully realized slickness of a quiet-luxury living room and the immersive, nostalgic dreaminess of a childhood playroom. The characters and the themes are familiar, but newly explored and enriched.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-f40000" name="image-f40000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9d4b31f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8dc9380/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89088a2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="7_Holiday Production Photos.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89088a2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/de4232f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/89088a2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4125x2315+0+173/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F95%2F16%2F4504ef71456da079a985ab8c0cfe%2F7-holiday-production-photos.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Bryce Gangel and Wesley Taylor portray the born-rich Seton siblings in The Goodman’s “Holiday.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Todd Rosenberg</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The most compelling performances here come from the actors playing the born-rich Seton siblings, as Greenberg has fleshed them out so completely. After all, he was once labeled, in a New York Times headline, as the “bard of American privilege.”</p><p>Griggs’ modern-day Julia has the compelling confidence of her father, who has invested in her wellness startup, but she also wonders whether she’s “an uncaring control freak.” (Her brother assures her she’s not uncaring.)</p><p>In Gangel’s deeply drawn depiction, Linda — who works with kids and has moved to Brooklyn — feels everyone’s wounds, especially her late mother’s, but her desire to “save” Julia from their father’s influence brings a response both fair and unfair at once: “What’s more privileged,” Julia asks her in an accusatory mode, “than being sad about being privileged?”</p><p>Ned is … well, right out of a Richard Greenberg play, and yet so much of him was there in Barry’s work too. Here he’s gay (which he probably was before but now it can be said) and Taylor delivers his emotional vulnerability with wit so droll that Ned comes across as so lovable and needy that Linda’s devotion to him — her co-dependence causes her to return to the house just to make sure he’s OK — feels utterly justifiable.</p><p>The weakness in this new “Holiday” is that Johnny is perhaps too much just the same as he always was, but blander. His belief that hard work and accumulation of wealth are means and not ends remains as relevant as ever, but that point of view, while contrary, isn’t nearly as surprising. Maybe the character doesn’t require updating the way the women, or the addict, do, but at least in Sottile’s take, he now comes off as flat amid a group of siblings who are fully dimensional.</p>
entries.author: Steven Oxman | For the Sun-Times

entries.title: Where to get paczki in Chicago
entries.summary: <p>Pączki Day — also known as Fat Tuesday — is the final day of indulgence before the Lenten season begins.</p><p>Pronounced PAWNCH-key, these are not doughnuts. The richer dough is deep fried and stuffed with cream, custard or traditional fillings of rose hip jam or prune. You can also veer off for trendy twists such as <a class="Link" href="https://www.alliancebakery.com/" target="_blank" ><u>Dubai chocolate or mango tajin</u>. </a></p><p>Here are 20 spots across Chicago offering the Polish pastries on Tuesday, Feb. 17. All sell the treats on Pączki Day — but get there early or call and order ahead to be sure you get yours.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/taste/2024/2/11/24068983/paczki-making-class-polish-dessert-fat-tuesday-delightful-pastries-chicago" >Eager bakers learn the art of making paczki, ahead of Fat Tuesday</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/food-drink/2025/10/29/polish-restaurants-chicago-spoko-pierogi-kitchen-staropolska-smakosz-red-apple-polish-paczki-cafe-polish-bistro" >Polish restaurants in Chicago: Where to find pierogi, borscht, pączki and more</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/food-drink/2026/02/12/polish-paczki-cafe-chicago-paczki-day" >At Polish Pączki Cafe, tradition is the secret ingredient</a> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-2e0000" name="html-embed-module-2e0000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-map" data-src="visualisation/27608834"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27608834/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="map visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p></p><h3><b>Chicago bakeries to get pączki on Pączki Day</b></h3><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0;padding-inline-start:48px;" id="rte-f0b30922-085a-11f1-a2a3-11c73bd949b5"><li><a class="Link" href="https://www.alliancebakery.com/" target="_blank" ><b><u>Alliance Bakery & Cafe</u></b></a>, 1837 W. entries.title: DHS afirma que un agente de la Patrulla Fronteriza fue ‘suspendido’ tras dispararle a una mujer de Chicago
entries.summary: <p>El agente de la Patrulla Fronteriza que disparó a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/04/marimar-martinez-baleada-por-agentes-de-migracion-se-pronuncia-contra-asesinatos" target="_blank" >Marimar Martínez</a> de Chicago, escribió una vez que sus superiores lo habían apoyado, “en grande”.</p><p>El comandante de la Patrulla Fronteriza, Gregory Bovino, lo elogió después del tiroteo. Dijo que el apoyo continuó en la cadena de mando, desde la secretaria de Seguridad Nacional, Kristi Noem, hasta alguien conocido como “El [mismo] Jefe”, que se podría referir al presidente Donald Trump.</p><p>Sin embargo, Martínez y sus abogados afirman que la <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/11/agentes-dijeron-es-hora-de-ser-agresivos-en-video-que-contradice-las-afirmaciones-contra-marimar-martinez" target="_blank" >nueva evidencia publicada</a> muestra que el agente de la Patrulla Fronteriza, Charles Exum, mintió para justificar el disparo. Y el miércoles, un portavoz de Aduanas y Protección Fronteriza (CBP) dijo que Exum “fue puesto en licencia administrativa”.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-820000" name="module-820000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>El portavoz, que hizo el comentario en un correo electrónico al Chicago Sun-Times, no respondió a un correo de seguimiento preguntando cuándo comenzó el descanso, o si aún está en efecto.</p><p>Aunque es un desarrollo progresivo, es notable que ocurre tras una campaña de varias semanas por parte de Martínez, a quien Exum le disparó cinco veces el 4 de octubre en el lado suroeste de la ciudad. Martínez decidió hablar el mes pasado después de que agentes de inmigración en Minneapolis le dispararan fatalmente a Renee Macklin Good y Alex Pretti.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Un correo electrónico del comandante de la Patrulla Fronteriza, Greg Bovino, al agente de la Patrulla Fronteriza, Charles Exum, después del tiroteo de Marimar Martínez el 4 de octubre en Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>U.S. Attorney’s Office</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Horas después del tiroteo de Martínez el otoño pasado, Bovino le dijo a Exum en un correo electrónico que quería retrasar la jubilación de Exum “más allá de los 57 años”.</p><p>“A la luz de tu excelente servicio en Chicago”, escribió Bovino, “¡aún tienes mucho por hacer!”.</p><p>Exum también testificó en noviembre que “nunca” había sido suspendido por la Patrulla Fronteriza.</p><p>Ahora, el portavoz de CBP dice que “todos los incidentes significativos de uso de la fuerza son investigados, revisados y presentados a la Junta Nacional de Revisión del Uso de la Fuerza”.</p><p>Los fiscales federales en Chicago presentaron cargos de asalto contra Martínez tras su encuentro con Exum. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2025/11/21/desestiman-el-caso-contra-mujer-a-la-que-le-disparo-agente-de-la-patrulla-fronteriza-en-brighton-park" target="_blank" >Desestimaron el caso el 20 de noviembre</a>, pero los funcionarios del Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS) han rechazado rescindir las afirmaciones anteriores de que es una “terrorista doméstica”.</p><p>Los abogados de Martínez llevaron a cabo una conferencia de prensa el miércoles para explicar cómo la evidencia recientemente publicada mostró que Exum y otros mintieron para justificar el tiroteo. Indicaron un diagrama dibujado por un agente de la escena del tiroteo.</p><p>El dibujo muestra tres vehículos delante de la Chevrolet Tahoe de Exum, además de la Nissan Rogue de Martínez y una GMC Envoy manejada por otro hombre que enfrentó cargos criminales.</p><p>El video muestra que los tres autos representados frente a la Tahoe de Exum “no existen”, dijo el abogado Christopher Parente.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-99a4ef" name="image-99a4ef"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/34846f1/2147483647/strip/true/crop/612x343+0+233/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F83%2Fa8%2F27f031b440118f7f8b16ea811849%2Ffbimain-001-000034.jpg data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/20e46ea/2147483647/strip/true/crop/612x343+0+233/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F83%2Fa8%2F27f031b440118f7f8b16ea811849%2Ffbimain-001-000034.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/20e46ea/2147483647/strip/true/crop/612x343+0+233/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F83%2Fa8%2F27f031b440118f7f8b16ea811849%2Ffbimain-001-000034.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c032e61/2147483647/strip/true/crop/612x343+0+233/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F83%2Fa8%2F27f031b440118f7f8b16ea811849%2Ffbimain-001-000034.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/20e46ea/2147483647/strip/true/crop/612x343+0+233/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F83%2Fa8%2F27f031b440118f7f8b16ea811849%2Ffbimain-001-000034.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Un diagrama elaborado por agentes federales de la escena del tiroteo del 4 de octubre de Marimar Martínez en Chicago.</p></figcaption></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>También disputó la afirmación de Exum al Buró Federal de Investigaciones (FBI) de que Exum disparó los cinco tiros a Martínez a través del parabrisas delantero. Parente dijo que tres fueron disparados al lado del pasajero de la Rogue, un cuarto “rompe la ventana trasera del pasajero”, y un quinto fue desde la parte trasera del auto de Martínez hacia el asiento delantero del pasajero.</p><p>Parente comentó que le han dicho que hay una investigación en curso sobre la conducta de Exum por parte de la oficina del fiscal en South Bend, Indiana. Pero no está claro en qué estado se encuentra esa investigación.</p><p>Parente y otros miembros del equipo legal de Martínez comentaron que planean presentar una queja bajo la Ley de Reclamaciones por Agravios Federales contra DHS y Exum.</p><p>“Este es un momento en el que simplemente no se puede confiar en las palabras de nuestros funcionarios federales”, aseguró Parente.</p><p>La evidencia en el caso de Martínez fue publicada el martes por la oficina del fiscal federal en Chicago, Andrew Boutros. Publicó los registros a pesar de que anteriormente se había opuesto a la divulgación de cierta evidencia, incluidos los mensajes de texto.</p><p>La jueza de distrito Georgia Alexakis <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/09/jueza-federal-permitira-a-marimar-martinez-publicar-mensajes-de-texto-enviados-por-el-agente-que-le-disparo" target="_blank" >le dio permiso a Martínez</a> el viernes para liberar la evidencia de todos modos. Al liberarla el martes, los fiscales anticiparon la conferencia de prensa de Martínez el miércoles.</p><p>Parente dijo que liberaron la evidencia “en el último momento en un intento mal guiado de minimizar cuán dañina que es para el gobierno”.</p><p>El 4 de octubre, Martínez siguió a la Tahoe manejada por Exum. Tocó su claxon, gritó “la migra” y trató de advertir a las personas sobre los agentes.</p><p>Dijo que colocó su Rogue junto a la Tahoe cerca de 39th Street y Kedzie Avenue, donde afirmó que Exum giró hacia su Rogue y sus vehículos se rozaron.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="113" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/nXGuQ7FrC38?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Border Patrol footage contradicts claims against Marimar Martinez"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p>En las imágenes de la cámara corporal del incidente, se escucha a los agentes que viajan en la Tahoe diciendo “es hora de ser agresivos” y “vamos a hacer contacto, estamos atrapados”.</p><p>Exum parece girar el volante hacia la izquierda, hacia el auto de Martínez, mientras su Tahoe chocó con la Rogue. Exum le dijo al FBI que “desvió su vehículo a la izquierda” después de la colisión “en un intento de crear espacio”.</p><p>Sin embargo, eso desautoriza la afirmación inicial de DHS de que Martínez “embistió” la Tahoe de Exum con su Rogue.</p><p>Después de la colisión, se puede escuchar a un agente diciendo “nos han golpeado, nos han golpeado”. Exum también se baja del vehículo y se oyen cinco disparos fuera de cámara.</p><p>Martínez dijo que detuvo su Rogue, pero temía ser agredida por los agentes, por lo que se alejó. Comentó que manejó lo “más a la izquierda posible” para evitar que los agentes salieran de su vehículo a su derecha. Pero al pasar, dijo que Exum abrió fuego.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ed8681" name="image-ed8681"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>U.S. Attorney’s office</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Exum escribió en un mensaje de texto que sus superiores lo habían apoyado después del tiroteo.</p><p>“Todos lo han sido, incluidos el jefe Bovino, el jefe Banks, la secretaria Noem y el [mismo] Jefe… según Bovino”, escribió Exum.</p><p>El agente incluso compartió un mensaje de alguien en Vermont. Decía, “Buen trabajo hermano, me alegra que estés a salvo y que puedas vivir para contar la historia. Eres una leyenda entre los agentes, mejor que lo sepas. Las cervezas van por mi cuenta cuando te vea en el entrenamiento”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Jon Seidel

entries.title: White Sox top pitching prospects Noah Schultz, Hagen Smith on track for '26 debuts — just not Opening Day
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — It's an open competition this spring training for at least two spots in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="_blank" ><u>White Sox</u></a>’ starting rotation, but don’t look for top pitching prospects Noah Schultz and Hagen Smith to break camp with the team.</p><p>After rocky seasons in minors last year for both of their highly touted left-handers, manager Will Venable said this week that he expects both Schultz and Smith to make their Major League debuts sometime this year, just not in March.</p><p>“We want to build them up to be starters,” Venable said. “They're gonna start most likely in Triple-A, and so we want to make sure that they're on their path.”</p><p>Schultz, an Oswego East High School product and the No. 49 prospect in baseball per MLB Pipeline, struggled last year after making the jump from Double-A Birmingham to Triple-A Charlotte. A nagging knee injury <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/09/25/white-sox-top-pitching-prospect-noah-schultz-embraces-growing-pains" target="_blank" ><u>cut his season short</u></a> and prevented him from playing in the Arizona Fall League.</p><p>Smith, the No. 72-ranked prospect, suffered his own bouts of inconsistency at Birmingham, but rebounded with <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/11/06/sox-prospect-hagen-smith-has-been-impressive-in-the-arizona-fall-league" target="_blank" ><u>a strong Fall League showing</u></a>. His lengthy season has him a bit behind schedule entering camp at Camelback Ranch.</p><p>“His ramp up will be thoughtful, and we'll make sure that he's in a good spot to get going in his Triple-A season to be pitching every fifth day and eventually with us in Chicago,” Venable said.</p><p>After a winter of rest — and a focus on finding consistency in his lanky mechanics — the 6-10 Schultz felt optimistic after throwing his first bullpen session Tuesday.</p><p>“Last year, I would get a little wild, lose hitters, throw a couple walks in there. It's not something that I've been used to in the past, but it's good that I can get back up,” said Schultz, whose fastball has topped out at 99 mph. “I'm excited.”</p><div class="Enhancement" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>White Sox prospect Hagen Smith throws two innings of an Arizona Fall League game at Camelback Ranch in Glendale, Arizona, on Nov. 4, 2025.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>John Antonoff/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Smith — a barrel-chested 6-3, with a fastball touching 97 — posted a 3.57 ERA over 12 Double-A starts last year, but he walked 56 batters in 75⅔ innings to go with 108 strikeouts. “I hold myself to a high standard. I didn’t meet that last year,” he said.</p><p>He spent his winter at home in eastern Texas dialing in his splitter/changeup in consultation with Sox pitching coaches. “I feel like I got a lot better this offseason and I want to prove it.”</p><p>Shane Smith, Davis Martin and Anthony Kay — signed out of South Korea’s KBO league — are poised to hold down the top end of the Sox’ rotation entering the season, while a wide cast vie for the remaining slots.</p><p>Returning right-hander and fellow KBO veteran Erick Fedde seems likely to get first crack at a spot after <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/02/11/erick-fedde-white-sox-return-prelander-berroa" target="_blank" ><u>signing a one-year, $1.5 million deal</u></a>.</p><p>Another free-agent signing, Sean Newcomb, brings more experience for Venable to shore up the staff, while Jonathan Cannon and Sean Burke are looking to regain their footing after bumpy seasons last year that resulted in late-season demotions for both.</p><p>Grant Taylor and Mike Vasil are pushing for starting opportunities, too, after bullpen success last year, while newcomers Chris Murphy, Jedixson Paez and David Sandlin could warrant consideration.</p><p>Over the winter, many fans had Schultz on that list of potentially cracking the big-league roster, too. While Venable hasn’t completely shut the door on that — anything’s possible at this early stage of the 2026 marathon — the towering lefty is not concerning himself with the idea.</p><p>“I have a ton of goals. There's a lot of things I could say, and I think staying healthy is the No. 1 thing,” Schultz said. “Improving some of the things that probably took a dip last year every day. Just getting 1% better every day.”</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p></p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: Long-sought Chicago police staffing study recommends adding more cops, hiring civilians
entries.summary: <p>A much-anticipated study on Chicago police staffing urges more hiring to better respond to community needs and offers a new model for how to best deploy officers with the resources available. </p><p>The study, conducted by Matrix Consulting Group, was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/2/5/24062649/how-best-deploy-chicago-police-officers-city-council-committee-vote" target="_blank" >commissioned by the City Council</a> in February 2024 to find ways to close gaps between police response times in different neighborhoods. </p><p>The group quickly determined the police department had “real and uneven staffing pressures,” with workloads varying significantly depending on district and unit, according to <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/WFA-ES.pdf" target="_blank" >an executive summary</a> released this week. </p><p>That resulted in inconsistent service and limited supervisory oversight in “high-demand areas,” the firm found. “This study examined every bureau, every unit and every function, down to the individual,” Allyson Clark Henson, the police department's executive director of constitutional policing and reform, told the Sun-Times.</p><p>“They provided us a foundational analytical framework that then allows us to guide a phased implementation, prioritizing what we think is most important to happen first.”</p><p>The study recommends shifting 600 cops out of jobs that could be done by people without police powers, then filling many of those positions with civilians. It also calls for hiring an additional 270 patrol officers and 90 patrol sergeants. </p><p>Instead of keeping a fixed number of officers in each district, the study argues that staffing should be adjusted regularly based on workloads. The department would also tackle challenges with oversight, with the study finding that “meaningful supervision becomes difficult” when sergeants are responsible for too many officers.</p><p>Robert Boik, senior vice president of public safety at the Civic Committee of the Commercial Club of Chicago, one of the study’s sponsors, said a supervisor at a police district could be overseeing close to 20 officers at any given time. </p><p>“We've invested a lot in accountability structures, but the most important layer of accountability is that relationship between the supervisor and the employee,” Boik said in an interview. “You could be the best manager in the world, but 20 is too much.”</p><p>Clark Henson and Boik said the key takeaway of the study is the long-term analytical model it provides for determining staffing. </p><p>“For years, CPD has deployed based on a set of internal metrics, and the study really provides a replicable, mathematically-based model that can serve as the basis for staffing for the first time ever and for years to come,” said Boik, Clark Henson’s predecessor. </p><p>The staffing analysis was required under <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/9/6/18327050/what-is-a-consent-decree" target="_blank" >a federal consent decree</a> mandating sweeping reforms in the wake of the police killing of Laquan McDonald. Similar studies were commissioned in 2016 and 2019, but were never completed, and preliminary results weren’t made public.</p><p>Six funders, including the Civic Committee, stepped up to fund the study, which ended up costing $780,000, according to Boik. A final report is expected to be released to the public in the coming weeks. </p><p>Police officials now have to weigh the recommendations while considering budget constraints and collective bargaining agreements. </p><p>“I'm looking forward to the final product,” said police Supt. Larry Snelling. “I don't expect it to be 100% perfect. I do expect that there may be some things that we need to look at and talk about, which is why we have this draft right now.”</p><p><i>Read the executive summary:</i></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/viewer?embedded=true&url=https://www.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/WFA-ES.pdf"></iframe> </div> </div></div><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/2/5/24062649/how-best-deploy-chicago-police-officers-city-council-committee-vote" target="_blank" >City Council committee OKs study on how best to deploy Chicago police as resources shrink, some crimes spike</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2024/10/25/chicago-police-department-exodus-suburbs-recruiting" target="_blank" >Chicago Police Department exodus: New cops are leaving in droves, Sun-Times investigation finds</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2025/11/05/chicago-police-hiring-slowdown-larry-snelling-brandon-johnson-budget" target="_blank" >CPD to slow hiring, pause academy training next summer to cut costs, superintendent says</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Sophie Sherry

entries.title: How ABS challenge system will affect MLB TV broadcasts
entries.summary: <p>Three seasons after adding the pitch clock to TV broadcasts, baseball producers now are figuring out how to handle the Automated Ball-Strike Challenge System, which will be part of MLB regular-season games beginning this season.</p><p>ABS was the biggest topic of discussion at the annual MLB production meetings last month in New York, where league officials and game producers from around the country address broadcast elements, new technologies and best practices. Though ABS won’t be as impactful as the pitch clock, it will affect TV broadcasts.</p><p>The strike-zone box, which has become as vital to baseball broadcasts as the first-down line on football broadcasts, will remain on the screen, but it no longer will indicate whether a pitch was a ball or a strike. In addition to showing the pitch speed and type, the box has marked a strike with a filled-in circle and a ball with a hollow circle. Home viewers might not have ever noticed.</p><p>The change was made because that box now will be used for the ABS system, and MLB is doing everything it can to ensure no one can exploit it. In fact, MLB will allow the box to be shown in just one place in the ballpark: the broadcast booth. More on that later.</p><p>Viewers still will know whether an obvious call merits a challenge. Challenges must be made immediately, so there’s no chance of a viewer contacting the team in time. Besides, only the batter, pitcher or catcher can issue a challenge, and he can’t have any assistance.</p><p>Once a player challenges a call, which he indicates by tapping his head, an animation of the pitch will be shown immediately on a videoboard in the stadium and on viewers’ screens. The call will be confirmed or overturned right then and there. No calls to replay umpires necessary.</p><p>The question for producers is how to display this for viewers. Do they add teams’ remaining challenges to an already-packed scorebug? How do they present the scene of challenges, which MLB said averaged only 14 seconds in spring-training trials last year?</p><p>Don’t expect challenges to appear in the scorebug. They’re more likely to appear in a graphic that slides out from the bug, like broadcasts do with mound visits. Teams start each game with two challenges and lose them only if they fail, so they could challenge more than two pitches.</p><p>Producers also could add drama to the scene by breaking the screen into boxes. Imagine a three-box with the graphic of the pitch and reactions from the batter and pitcher. In a key spot in the ninth inning, that could make for good TV.</p><p>How teams use challenges should make for good discussion among broadcasters. Producers have learned that teams already are discussing strategy, such as which players can or can’t initiate a challenge. Pitchers who think everything they throw is a strike and hitters who lack a great feel for the strike zone probably won’t be allowed to. And broadcasters will have more to discuss once enough data is compiled about team tendencies regarding challenges.</p><p>But the addition isn’t without headaches for production crews. MLB’s biggest point of emphasis at the production meetings was the change to the availability of the broadcast with the strike-zone box. MLB doesn’t want that feed shown anywhere in the ballpark, outside of the broadcast booth, to prevent teams from taking advantage of it.</p><p>That means players in the clubhouse and dugout and fans waiting in line for concessions won’t see the strike-zone box on nearby TVs. Technical teams from local and national outlets have spent a lot of time figuring out how to change the feeds they send through the ballpark. It won’t affect home viewers.</p><p>Producers don’t expect ABS challenges to provide many dramatic moments to display, and they want to be careful not to overdo them. The challenge system might just blend into the game as quietly as the pitch clock has. But in big moments, those 14 seconds could provide some compelling sights.</p><h3>Remote patrol</h3><p>The Cubs and White Sox announced their spring-training broadcast information this week:</p><p>• For the Cubs, Marquee Sports Network will air 11 games and The Score 10. Both will carry the Cubs’ first two games, the opener next Friday against the Sox and the game Feb. 21.</p><p>• For the Sox, Chicago Sports Network will air nine games, and 10 will air on ESPN 1000, which will carry the opener next Friday against the Cubs. CHSN will carry the next two games.<br></p>
entries.author: Jeff Agrest
